{"content_type": "tether_quote", "url": "https://dohanews.co/world-reacts-to-israels-war-on-lebanon/", "domain": "dohanews.co", "text": "\nThe Iraqi PM described Nasrallah as \u201ca martyr on the path of the righteous\u201d.\n\n### Iran\u00a0\n\nIranian President Masoud Pezeshkian said on Saturday that the killing of Nasrallah \u201cwill only further strengthen the resistance.\u201d\n\nIran will observe a \u301020\u2020five day period\u2020en.royanews.tv\u3011 of public mourning for the Hezbollah chief.\n\nPezeshkian also pointed fingers at the US, saying Washington cannot deny complicity in Nasrallah\u2019s killing.\n\n### Syria\n\nThe Syrian government has declared a \u301021\u2020three-day official mourning period\u2020sana.sy\u3011. Flags will be lowered at half-mast across Syria and in all embassies and diplomatic missions abroad.\n\n\u201cToday, the brotherly Lebanon has lost Secretary-General of Hezbollah, Sayyed Hassan Nasrallah, as a result of a brutal and cowardly Israeli aggression that targeted with tons of destructive bombs a residential area in the southern suburb of Beirut, which led to his martyrdom along with a large number of innocent civilians,\u201d Syria\u2019s Foreign and Expatriates Ministry said in a statement.\n\n### Russia\n\nRussia\u2019s foreign ministry strongly condemned Israel\u2019s killing of Nasrallah in Beirut, calling it \u201cyet another political assassination\u201d.\n\n\u201cThis forceful action is fraught with even greater dramatic consequences for Lebanon and the entire Middle East,\u201d \u301022\u2020Russia said in a statement\u2020mid.ru\u3011.\n\n\u201cThe Israeli side could not fail to recognise this danger, but took the step of killing Lebanese citizens, which would almost inevitably provoke a new outburst of violence. Thus, it bears full responsibility for the subsequent escalation,\u201d the foreign ministry added.\n\n### Palestine\n\nPalestinian Authority President Mahmoud Abbas expressed his condolences to Lebanon, in a statement published by Palestinian state news agency \u301023\u2020WAFA\u2020english.wafa.ps\u3011.\n\nAbbas said he \u201cextended his heartfelt sympathies to the Lebanese government and the brotherly people of Lebanon over the civilian casualties resulting from the ongoing Israeli aggression\u201d.\n\n### Turkey\n\nTurkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan has accused Israel of committing a \u201cgenocide\u201d in Lebanon.\n\n\u201cLebanon and the Lebanese people are the latest target of a policy of genocide, occupation, and invasion carried out by Israel since October 7,\u201d Erdogan said on \u301024\u2020social media .\u2020x.com\u3011\n\nTurkey\u2019s Foreign Minister Hakan Fidan told broadcaster \u301025\u2020TRT Haber\u2020www.trthaber.com\u3011 in New York that \u201cNasrallah was an important figure in the region. He was an important figure for Lebanon.\u201d\n\n\u201cI honestly think that the void left by his absence will be difficult to fill,\u201d he said. \u201cNasrallah\u2019s death was a great loss for both Hezbollah and Iran.\u201d\n\n### Amal political movement\n\nLebanon\u2019s Amal Movement released a\u301026\u2020 statement\u2020www.nna-leb.gov.lb\u3011 describing Nasrallah as a \u201cunique and courageous figure\u201d, adding that his death would not weaken \u201cthe resolve of the resistance fighters\u201d.\n\nThe Amal movement went on to say that the Israeli \u201ckilling and aggression will only increase our steadfastness in defending Lebanon\u201d.\n\n### Hamas\n\nPalestinian movement Hamas denounced Israel\u2019s Friday attack in Lebanon, and expressed its condolences and solidarity to the Lebanese people and resistance. \n\n\u201cWe condemn in the strongest terms this barbaric Zionist aggression and the targeting of residential buildings in the southern suburb of Beirut, and we consider this a cowardly act of terrorism, a massacre and a heinous crime, which proves once again the bloodiness and brutality of this occupation,\u201d Hamas said in a \u301027\u2020statement\u2020hamasinfo.info\u3011.\u00a0\n\n### Houthis\n\nThe Houthi movement, officially known as\u00a0Ansar Allah, have also \u301028\u2020mourned Nasrallah\u2020www.yemenmonitor.com\u3011, with leader Abdul Malik al-Houthi saying his death \u201cwill not be in vain\u201d.\n\n\u201cThe martyrdom of \u2026 Hassan Nasrallah will increase the flame of sacrifice, the heat of enthusiasm, the strength of resolve.\u201d\n\n\u201cThese great sacrifices and great injustice will not be wasted,\u201d he said in a speech.\u00a0\n\n### United States\n\nUS President Joe Biden issued a statement on Nasrallah\u2019s death, calling it \u201ca measure of justice for his many victims, including thousands of Americans, Israelis, and Lebanese civilians\u201d.\n\nWhen asked on a possible Israeli ground invasion into Lebanon, Biden \u301029\u2020said\u2020www.youtube.com\u3011 that it was \u201ctime for a ceasefire now\u201d.\n\nVice President and 2024 presidential race candidate Kamala Harris called Nasrallah \u201ca terrorist with American blood on his hands\u201d.\n\n\u201cAcross decades, his leadership of Hezbollah destabilised the Middle East and led to the killing of countless innocent people in Lebanon, Israel, Syria, and around the world. Today, Hezbollah\u2019s victims have a measure of justice,\u201d the VP said in an \u301030\u2020official statement.\u2020www.whitehouse.gov\u3011\n\n\u201cI have an unwavering commitment to the security of Israel. I will always support Israel\u2019s right to defend itself against Iran a", "title": "World reacts to Israel&#x27;s war on Lebanon - Doha News | Qatar", "tether_id": null}, "status": "finished_successfully", "end_turn": null, "weight": 0.0, "metadata": {"_cite_metadata": {"citation_format": {"name": "tether_og"}, "metadata_list": [{"type": "webpage", "title": "World reacts to Israel&#x27;s war on Lebanon - Doha News | Qatar", "url": "https://dohanews.co/world-reacts-to-israels-war-on-lebanon/", "text": "\nThe Iraqi PM described Nasrallah as \u201ca martyr on the path of the righteous\u201d.\n\n### Iran\u00a0\n\nIranian President Masoud Pezeshkian said on Saturday that the killing of Nasrallah \u201cwill only further strengthen the resistance.\u201d\n\nIran will observe a \u301020\u2020five day period\u2020en.royanews.tv\u3011 of public mourning for the Hezbollah chief.\n\nPezeshkian also pointed fingers at the US, saying Washington cannot deny complicity in Nasrallah\u2019s killing.\n\n### Syria\n\nThe Syrian government has declared a \u301021\u2020three-day official mourning period\u2020sana.sy\u3011. Flags will be lowered at half-mast across Syria and in all embassies and diplomatic missions abroad.\n\n\u201cToday, the brotherly Lebanon has lost Secretary-General of Hezbollah, Sayyed Hassan Nasrallah, as a result of a brutal and cowardly Israeli aggression that targeted with tons of destructive bombs a residential area in the southern suburb of Beirut, which led to his martyrdom along with a large number of innocent civilians,\u201d Syria\u2019s Foreign and Expatriates Ministry said in a statement.\n\n### Russia\n\nRussia\u2019s foreign ministry strongly condemned Israel\u2019s killing of Nasrallah in Beirut, calling it \u201cyet another political assassination\u201d.\n\n\u201cThis forceful action is fraught with even greater dramatic consequences for Lebanon and the entire Middle East,\u201d \u301022\u2020Russia said in a statement\u2020mid.ru\u3011.\n\n\u201cThe Israeli side could not fail to recognise this danger, but took the step of killing Lebanese citizens, which would almost inevitably provoke a new outburst of violence. Thus, it bears full responsibility for the subsequent escalation,\u201d the foreign ministry added.\n\n### Palestine\n\nPalestinian Authority President Mahmoud Abbas expressed his condolences to Lebanon, in a statement published by Palestinian state news agency \u301023\u2020WAFA\u2020english.wafa.ps\u3011.\n\nAbbas said he \u201cextended his heartfelt sympathies to the Lebanese government and the brotherly people of Lebanon over the civilian casualties resulting from the ongoing Israeli aggression\u201d.\n\n### Turkey\n\nTurkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan has accused Israel of committing a \u201cgenocide\u201d in Lebanon.\n\n\u201cLebanon and the Lebanese people are the latest target of a policy of genocide, occupation, and invasion carried out by Israel since October 7,\u201d Erdogan said on \u301024\u2020social media .\u2020x.com\u3011\n\nTurkey\u2019s Foreign Minister Hakan Fidan told broadcaster \u301025\u2020TRT Haber\u2020www.trthaber.com\u3011 in New York that \u201cNasrallah was an important figure in the region. He was an important figure for Lebanon.\u201d\n\n\u201cI honestly think that the void left by his absence will be difficult to fill,\u201d he said. \u201cNasrallah\u2019s death was a great loss for both Hezbollah and Iran.\u201d\n\n### Amal political movement\n\nLebanon\u2019s Amal Movement released a\u301026\u2020 statement\u2020www.nna-leb.gov.lb\u3011 describing Nasrallah as a \u201cunique and courageous figure\u201d, adding that his death would not weaken \u201cthe resolve of the resistance fighters\u201d.\n\nThe Amal movement went on to say that the Israeli \u201ckilling and aggression will only increase our steadfastness in defending Lebanon\u201d.\n\n### Hamas\n\nPalestinian movement Hamas denounced Israel\u2019s Friday attack in Lebanon, and expressed its condolences and solidarity to the Lebanese people and resistance. \n\n\u201cWe condemn in the strongest terms this barbaric Zionist aggression and the targeting of residential buildings in the southern suburb of Beirut, and we consider this a cowardly act of terrorism, a massacre and a heinous crime, which proves once again the bloodiness and brutality of this occupation,\u201d Hamas said in a \u301027\u2020statement\u2020hamasinfo.info\u3011.\u00a0\n\n### Houthis\n\nThe Houthi movement, officially known as\u00a0Ansar Allah, have also \u301028\u2020mourned Nasrallah\u2020www.yemenmonitor.com\u3011, with leader Abdul Malik al-Houthi saying his death \u201cwill not be in vain\u201d.\n\n\u201cThe martyrdom of \u2026 Hassan Nasrallah will increase the flame of sacrifice, the heat of enthusiasm, the strength of resolve.\u201d\n\n\u201cThese great sacrifices and great injustice will not be wasted,\u201d he said in a speech.\u00a0\n\n### United States\n\nUS President Joe Biden issued a statement on Nasrallah\u2019s death, calling it \u201ca measure of justice for his many victims, including thousands of Americans, Israelis, and Lebanese civilians\u201d.\n\nWhen asked on a possible Israeli ground invasion into Lebanon, Biden \u301029\u2020said\u2020www.youtube.com\u3011 that it was \u201ctime for a ceasefire now\u201d.\n\nVice President and 2024 presidential race candidate Kamala Harris called Nasrallah \u201ca terrorist with American blood on his hands\u201d.\n\n\u201cAcross decades, his leadership of Hezbollah destabilised the Middle East and led to the killing of countless innocent people in Lebanon, Israel, Syria, and around the world. Today, Hezbollah\u2019s victims have a measure of justice,\u201d the VP said in an \u301030\u2020official statement.\u2020www.whitehouse.gov\u3011\n\n\u201cI have an unwavering commitment to the security of Israel. I will always support Israel\u2019s right to defend itself against Iran a", "pub_date": null, "extra": null}], "original_query": null}, "command": "mclick", "args": ["[0, 1, 2, 4, 5, 6]"], "status": "finished", "is_complete": true, "message_type": null, "model_slug": "gpt-4o", "default_model_slug": "gpt-4o", "parent_id": "ec86b357-a1c7-4420-a06f-117b19640105", "request_id": "8cb3ce3dab260e27-MXP", "timestamp_": "absolute"}, "recipient": "all", "channel": null}, "parent": "ec86b357-a1c7-4420-a06f-117b19640105", "children": ["da533943-4428-4402-a6d2-faf447182b3c"]}, "da533943-4428-4402-a6d2-faf447182b3c": {"id": "da533943-4428-4402-a6d2-faf447182b3c", "message": {"id": "da533943-4428-4402-a6d2-faf447182b3c", "author": {"role": "tool", "name": "browser", "metadata": {}}, "create_time": 1727695089.716294, "update_time": null, "content": {"content_type": "tether_quote", "url": "https://www.britannica.com/event/Lebanese-Civil-War", "domain": "www.britannica.com", "text": "(Show\u00a0more)\n\nMajor Events: \n    \u301085\u20201983 Beirut barracks bombings\u3011\n(Show\u00a0more)\n\nKey People: \n    \u301086\u2020Michel Aoun\u3011\n    \u301087\u2020Bashir Gemayel\u3011\n    \u301088\u2020Pierre Gemayel\u3011\n(Show\u00a0more)\n\n\u301057\u2020 See all related content \u2192\u3011 \n\nAsk the Chatbot a Question  Ask the Chatbot a Question \n\nLebanese Civil War, civil conflict (1975\u201390) in \u301083\u2020Lebanon\u3011 emanating from the deterioration of the Lebanese state and the coalescence of militias that provided security where the state could not. These militias formed largely along communal lines: the Lebanese Front (LF), led by the Phalangists (or Phalange), represented \u301089\u2020Maronite\u3011 Christian clans whose leaders had dominated the traditional elite class of the country\u2019s sociopolitical fabric; the Lebanese National Movement (LNM), a coalition of \u301090\u2020secular\u2020www.merriam-webster.com\u3011 leftists and \u301091\u2020Sunni\u3011 Muslims sympathetic to \u301092\u2020Arab nationalism\u3011; the Amal (\u201cHope,\u201d also an \u301093\u2020acronym\u2020www.merriam-webster.com\u3011 for Afw\u0101j al-Muq\u0101wamah al-Lubn\u0101niyyah [Lebanese Resistance Detachments]) movement, \u301094\u2020comprising\u2020www.merriam-webster.com\u3011 \u301095\u2020Shi\u02bfi\u3011 populists; and the \u301084\u2020Palestine Liberation Organization\u3011 (PLO), which represented Lebanon\u2019s large Palestinian refugee population. Other participants in the \u301096\u2020war\u3011 included \u301097\u2020Syria\u3011, \u301098\u2020Israel\u3011, and splintered \u301099\u2020contingents\u2020www.merriam-webster.com\u3011 of the Lebanese Army.\n\n## Background\n\nThe causes of the war were multifaceted and deeply rooted but can be generalized as a growing crisis of insecurity. After he played a key role as commander of the army in resolving the crisis of a 1958 rebellion, the newly elected president \u3010100\u2020Fuad Chehab\u3011 made a valiant attempt to address the disproportionate development of the country and to centralize the state\u2019s security apparatus. By the late 1960s, however, the development program he initiated proved politically unsatisfactory and had become a destabilizing force. The strengthened security apparatus, meanwhile, gained a reputation for suppression and corruption. The situation grew more \u3010101\u2020precarious\u3011 as the government negotiated the presence and operation of PLO guerrillas inside Lebanon\u2019s Palestinian refugee camps, which had attracted Israeli raids on Lebanon, most notably on the airport in \u3010102\u2020Beirut\u3011 in 1968. As the state proved increasingly unable to maintain a monopoly of force, patronage networks, both existing and new, began arming and organizing their own security.\n\n\u301061\u2020 Britannica Quiz A History of War \u3011\n\nOn August 17, 1970, \u3010103\u2020Suleiman Franjieh\u3011, leader of a powerful Maronite clan from northern Lebanon who sought to undo the reform program initiated by Chehab, was elected president by one vote after three rounds of balloting. His presidency, polarizing and corrupt, alienated Muslims and Christians alike, and his government proved unable to maintain the state\u2019s dominance over the growing and diffuse militias of the PLO. The Phalangist militia of the rival Maronite \u3010104\u2020Gemayel clan\u3011 began taking matters into its own hands by confronting the Palestinian militias directly.\n\n## Progression of the war\n\nThe beginning of the civil war is typically dated to April 13, 1975, when the Phalangists attacked a bus taking Palestinians to a refugee camp at \u3010105\u2020Tall al-Za\u02bftar\u3011, Lebanon. The attack escalated an \u3010106\u2020intermittent\u2020www.merriam-webster.com\u3011 cycle of violence into a more general battle between the Phalangists and the LNM, whose coalition of Lebanese leftists and Muslims supported the PLO\u2019s cause.\n\nIn the months that followed, the general destruction of the central market area of Beirut was marked by the emergence of a \u201cgreen line\u201d between Muslim West Beirut and Christian East Beirut, which persisted until the end of the civil war in 1990, with each side under the control of its respective militias.\n\nAs Franjieh\u2019s term came to an end, and with Lebanon\u2019s army splintered, he asked Syria to intervene to prevent the country from disintegrating into multiple states. Despite its earlier support for the PLO in the south, Syria launched a large-scale intervention to \u3010107\u2020redress\u3011 the emerging imbalance of power in favour of the Christians in the north. Syria\u2019s intervention sparked a more active Israeli involvement as well, in which Israel armed and financed Christian militias in the south of the country, whom Israelis looked upon as their", "title": "Lebanese Civil War | History, &amp; Significance | Britannica", "tether_id": null}, "status": "finished_successfully", "end_turn": null, "weight": 0.0, "metadata": {"_cite_metadata": {"citation_format": {"name": "tether_og"}, "metadata_list": [{"type": "webpage", "title": "Lebanese Civil War | History, &amp; Significance | Britannica", "url": "https://www.britannica.com/event/Lebanese-Civil-War", "text": "(Show\u00a0more)\n\nMajor Events: \n    \u301085\u20201983 Beirut barracks bombings\u3011\n(Show\u00a0more)\n\nKey People: \n    \u301086\u2020Michel Aoun\u3011\n    \u301087\u2020Bashir Gemayel\u3011\n    \u301088\u2020Pierre Gemayel\u3011\n(Show\u00a0more)\n\n\u301057\u2020 See all related content \u2192\u3011 \n\nAsk the Chatbot a Question  Ask the Chatbot a Question \n\nLebanese Civil War, civil conflict (1975\u201390) in \u301083\u2020Lebanon\u3011 emanating from the deterioration of the Lebanese state and the coalescence of militias that provided security where the state could not. These militias formed largely along communal lines: the Lebanese Front (LF), led by the Phalangists (or Phalange), represented \u301089\u2020Maronite\u3011 Christian clans whose leaders had dominated the traditional elite class of the country\u2019s sociopolitical fabric; the Lebanese National Movement (LNM), a coalition of \u301090\u2020secular\u2020www.merriam-webster.com\u3011 leftists and \u301091\u2020Sunni\u3011 Muslims sympathetic to \u301092\u2020Arab nationalism\u3011; the Amal (\u201cHope,\u201d also an \u301093\u2020acronym\u2020www.merriam-webster.com\u3011 for Afw\u0101j al-Muq\u0101wamah al-Lubn\u0101niyyah [Lebanese Resistance Detachments]) movement, \u301094\u2020comprising\u2020www.merriam-webster.com\u3011 \u301095\u2020Shi\u02bfi\u3011 populists; and the \u301084\u2020Palestine Liberation Organization\u3011 (PLO), which represented Lebanon\u2019s large Palestinian refugee population. Other participants in the \u301096\u2020war\u3011 included \u301097\u2020Syria\u3011, \u301098\u2020Israel\u3011, and splintered \u301099\u2020contingents\u2020www.merriam-webster.com\u3011 of the Lebanese Army.\n\n## Background\n\nThe causes of the war were multifaceted and deeply rooted but can be generalized as a growing crisis of insecurity. After he played a key role as commander of the army in resolving the crisis of a 1958 rebellion, the newly elected president \u3010100\u2020Fuad Chehab\u3011 made a valiant attempt to address the disproportionate development of the country and to centralize the state\u2019s security apparatus. By the late 1960s, however, the development program he initiated proved politically unsatisfactory and had become a destabilizing force. The strengthened security apparatus, meanwhile, gained a reputation for suppression and corruption. The situation grew more \u3010101\u2020precarious\u3011 as the government negotiated the presence and operation of PLO guerrillas inside Lebanon\u2019s Palestinian refugee camps, which had attracted Israeli raids on Lebanon, most notably on the airport in \u3010102\u2020Beirut\u3011 in 1968. As the state proved increasingly unable to maintain a monopoly of force, patronage networks, both existing and new, began arming and organizing their own security.\n\n\u301061\u2020 Britannica Quiz A History of War \u3011\n\nOn August 17, 1970, \u3010103\u2020Suleiman Franjieh\u3011, leader of a powerful Maronite clan from northern Lebanon who sought to undo the reform program initiated by Chehab, was elected president by one vote after three rounds of balloting. His presidency, polarizing and corrupt, alienated Muslims and Christians alike, and his government proved unable to maintain the state\u2019s dominance over the growing and diffuse militias of the PLO. The Phalangist militia of the rival Maronite \u3010104\u2020Gemayel clan\u3011 began taking matters into its own hands by confronting the Palestinian militias directly.\n\n## Progression of the war\n\nThe beginning of the civil war is typically dated to April 13, 1975, when the Phalangists attacked a bus taking Palestinians to a refugee camp at \u3010105\u2020Tall al-Za\u02bftar\u3011, Lebanon. The attack escalated an \u3010106\u2020intermittent\u2020www.merriam-webster.com\u3011 cycle of violence into a more general battle between the Phalangists and the LNM, whose coalition of Lebanese leftists and Muslims supported the PLO\u2019s cause.\n\nIn the months that followed, the general destruction of the central market area of Beirut was marked by the emergence of a \u201cgreen line\u201d between Muslim West Beirut and Christian East Beirut, which persisted until the end of the civil war in 1990, with each side under the control of its respective militias.\n\nAs Franjieh\u2019s term came to an end, and with Lebanon\u2019s army splintered, he asked Syria to intervene to prevent the country from disintegrating into multiple states. Despite its earlier support for the PLO in the south, Syria launched a large-scale intervention to \u3010107\u2020redress\u3011 the emerging imbalance of power in favour of the Christians in the north. Syria\u2019s intervention sparked a more active Israeli involvement as well, in which Israel armed and financed Christian militias in the south of the country, whom Israelis looked upon as their", "pub_date": null, "extra": null}], "original_query": null}, "command": "mclick", "args": ["[0, 1, 2, 4, 5, 6]"], "status": "finished", "is_complete": true, "message_type": null, "model_slug": "gpt-4o", "default_model_slug": "gpt-4o", "parent_id": "f8a1a32f-40a0-42c0-98f1-a2bb45fbd1cf", "request_id": "8cb3ce3dab260e27-MXP", "timestamp_": "absolute"}, "recipient": "all", "channel": null}, "parent": "f8a1a32f-40a0-42c0-98f1-a2bb45fbd1cf", "children": ["df74c2e4-f592-4e88-bae6-7d5d5b8e6e81"]}, "df74c2e4-f592-4e88-bae6-7d5d5b8e6e81": {"id": "df74c2e4-f592-4e88-bae6-7d5d5b8e6e81", "message": {"id": "df74c2e4-f592-4e88-bae6-7d5d5b8e6e81", "author": {"role": "tool", "name": "browser", "metadata": {}}, "create_time": 1727695089.716371, "update_time": null, "content": {"content_type": "tether_quote", "url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1983_US_embassy_bombing_in_Beirut", "domain": "en.wikipedia.org", "text": "\nThe next day, Ambassador Robert Dillon, who had narrowly escaped injury in the bombing, said: &quot;Paramount among the essential business is our work for the withdrawal of all foreign forces from Lebanon.&quot; It is only by securing Lebanese government control over the country &quot;that terrible tragedies like the one we experienced yesterday can be avoided in the future.&quot;[ 5 ]\n\nThe President of Lebanon, \u3010102\u2020Amine Gemayel\u3011, cabled President Reagan on April 18, saying, &quot;The Lebanese people and myself express our deepest condolences to the families of the U.S. victims. The cross of peace is the burden of the courageous.&quot;[ 5 ] Meanwhile, Lebanon asked the United States, France, and Italy to double the size of the peacekeeping force. As of March 16, it numbered about 4,800 troops, including some 1,200 US Marines, 1,400 Italian soldiers, 2,100 French paratroopers and 100 British soldiers. \n\n\u3010103\u2020Iran\u3011 denied any role in the attack. Foreign Minister, \u3010104\u2020Ali Akbar Velayati\u3011 said, &quot;We deny any involvement and we think this allegation is another propaganda plot against us.&quot;[ 7 ]\n\nOn April 19, Prime Minister \u3010105\u2020Menachem Begin\u3011 of Israel sent President Reagan a message of condolence for the embassy bombing. &quot;I write in the name of Israel when I express to you my deep shock at the terrible outrage which took the lives of so many of the American embassy in Beirut yesterday.&quot;[ 5 ] Defense Minister \u3010106\u2020Moshe Arens\u3011, was quoted by Israeli radio that he told the cabinet the attack &quot;justified Israel&#x27;s demands for security arrangements in Lebanon.&quot; Minister \u3010107\u2020Yitzhak Shamir\u3011 of Israel called the embassy bombing &quot;shocking&quot; but added that, &quot;In Lebanon nothing is surprising. I think the lesson is simple and understood. The security problems in Lebanon are still most serious, and terrorist organizations will continue to operate there, at times with great success.&quot;[ 5 ]\n\n## U.S. economic aid\n\n[\u3010108\u2020edit\u3011]\n\nThe \u3010109\u2020House Foreign Affairs Committee\u3011 April 19 voted to approve $251 million in additional economic and military aid for Lebanon, as requested by the administration. But it attached an amendment to the bill that would force the White House to seek approval for any expanded US military role. \n\nThe \u3010110\u2020Senate Foreign Relations Committee\u3011 followed suit April 20, approving the aid request but attaching an amendment that required the president to obtain congressional authorization for &quot;any substantial expansion in the number or role of US armed forces in Lebanon or for the creation of a new, expanded or extended multinational peacekeeping force in Lebanon.&quot; If Congress did not act jointly on such a request within 60 days, however, the increase would then take effect automatically. \n\nThe Senate amendment was sponsored as a compromise by the committee&#x27;s chairman, Republican \u3010111\u2020Charles H. Percy\u3011 of Illinois. It prevented a move by the committee&#x27;s ranking Democrat, \u3010112\u2020Claiborne Pell\u3011 of Rhode Island, to extend the 1973 \u3010113\u2020War Powers Resolution\u3011 to Lebanon. On April 20, Pell said he would have had the votes to apply the resolution to US Marines in Lebanon. The law limited presidential commitment of troops in hostile situations to a maximum of 90 days unless Congress specifically approved their use. \n\nDeputy Secretary of State \u3010114\u2020Kenneth W. Dam\u3011, in a letter to the committee, had argued forcefully against use of the War Powers Resolution. Dam said it would &quot;amount to a public finding that US forces will be exposed to imminent risk of involvement in hostilities&quot;, which &quot;could give entirely the wrong public impression&quot; of US expectations for Lebanon&#x27;s future. Several influential congressmen had been urging an end to the US military role in Lebanon. After the embassy bombing, April 19, Republican Senator \u3010115\u2020Barry Goldwater\u3011 of Arizona said, &quot;I think it&#x27;s high time we bring the boys home.&quot; \n\n## Aftermath\n\n[\u3010116\u2020edit\u3011]\n\n  * \u3010117\u2020v\u3011\n  * \u3010118\u2020t\u3011\n  * \u3010119\u2020e\u3011\n\n\u301069\u2020Lebanese Civil War\u3011  \n\nFirst phase: 1975\u20131977  \n\n  * \u3010120\u2020Bus massacre\u3011\n  * \u3010121\u2020Black Thursday\u3011\n  * \u3010122\u2020Battle of the Hotels\u3011\n  * \u3010123\u2020ASALA insurgency\u3011\n  * \u3010124\u2020Black Saturday\u3011\n  * \u3010125\u2020Karantina massacre\u3011\n  * \u3010126\u2020Damour massa", "title": "1983 US embassy bombing in Beirut - Wikipedia", "tether_id": null}, "status": "finished_successfully", "end_turn": null, "weight": 0.0, "metadata": {"_cite_metadata": {"citation_format": {"name": "tether_og"}, "metadata_list": [{"type": "webpage", "title": "1983 US embassy bombing in Beirut - Wikipedia", "url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1983_US_embassy_bombing_in_Beirut", "text": "\nThe next day, Ambassador Robert Dillon, who had narrowly escaped injury in the bombing, said: &quot;Paramount among the essential business is our work for the withdrawal of all foreign forces from Lebanon.&quot; It is only by securing Lebanese government control over the country &quot;that terrible tragedies like the one we experienced yesterday can be avoided in the future.&quot;[ 5 ]\n\nThe President of Lebanon, \u3010102\u2020Amine Gemayel\u3011, cabled President Reagan on April 18, saying, &quot;The Lebanese people and myself express our deepest condolences to the families of the U.S. victims. The cross of peace is the burden of the courageous.&quot;[ 5 ] Meanwhile, Lebanon asked the United States, France, and Italy to double the size of the peacekeeping force. As of March 16, it numbered about 4,800 troops, including some 1,200 US Marines, 1,400 Italian soldiers, 2,100 French paratroopers and 100 British soldiers. \n\n\u3010103\u2020Iran\u3011 denied any role in the attack. Foreign Minister, \u3010104\u2020Ali Akbar Velayati\u3011 said, &quot;We deny any involvement and we think this allegation is another propaganda plot against us.&quot;[ 7 ]\n\nOn April 19, Prime Minister \u3010105\u2020Menachem Begin\u3011 of Israel sent President Reagan a message of condolence for the embassy bombing. &quot;I write in the name of Israel when I express to you my deep shock at the terrible outrage which took the lives of so many of the American embassy in Beirut yesterday.&quot;[ 5 ] Defense Minister \u3010106\u2020Moshe Arens\u3011, was quoted by Israeli radio that he told the cabinet the attack &quot;justified Israel&#x27;s demands for security arrangements in Lebanon.&quot; Minister \u3010107\u2020Yitzhak Shamir\u3011 of Israel called the embassy bombing &quot;shocking&quot; but added that, &quot;In Lebanon nothing is surprising. I think the lesson is simple and understood. The security problems in Lebanon are still most serious, and terrorist organizations will continue to operate there, at times with great success.&quot;[ 5 ]\n\n## U.S. economic aid\n\n[\u3010108\u2020edit\u3011]\n\nThe \u3010109\u2020House Foreign Affairs Committee\u3011 April 19 voted to approve $251 million in additional economic and military aid for Lebanon, as requested by the administration. But it attached an amendment to the bill that would force the White House to seek approval for any expanded US military role. \n\nThe \u3010110\u2020Senate Foreign Relations Committee\u3011 followed suit April 20, approving the aid request but attaching an amendment that required the president to obtain congressional authorization for &quot;any substantial expansion in the number or role of US armed forces in Lebanon or for the creation of a new, expanded or extended multinational peacekeeping force in Lebanon.&quot; If Congress did not act jointly on such a request within 60 days, however, the increase would then take effect automatically. \n\nThe Senate amendment was sponsored as a compromise by the committee&#x27;s chairman, Republican \u3010111\u2020Charles H. Percy\u3011 of Illinois. It prevented a move by the committee&#x27;s ranking Democrat, \u3010112\u2020Claiborne Pell\u3011 of Rhode Island, to extend the 1973 \u3010113\u2020War Powers Resolution\u3011 to Lebanon. On April 20, Pell said he would have had the votes to apply the resolution to US Marines in Lebanon. The law limited presidential commitment of troops in hostile situations to a maximum of 90 days unless Congress specifically approved their use. \n\nDeputy Secretary of State \u3010114\u2020Kenneth W. Dam\u3011, in a letter to the committee, had argued forcefully against use of the War Powers Resolution. Dam said it would &quot;amount to a public finding that US forces will be exposed to imminent risk of involvement in hostilities&quot;, which &quot;could give entirely the wrong public impression&quot; of US expectations for Lebanon&#x27;s future. Several influential congressmen had been urging an end to the US military role in Lebanon. After the embassy bombing, April 19, Republican Senator \u3010115\u2020Barry Goldwater\u3011 of Arizona said, &quot;I think it&#x27;s high time we bring the boys home.&quot; \n\n## Aftermath\n\n[\u3010116\u2020edit\u3011]\n\n  * \u3010117\u2020v\u3011\n  * \u3010118\u2020t\u3011\n  * \u3010119\u2020e\u3011\n\n\u301069\u2020Lebanese Civil War\u3011  \n\nFirst phase: 1975\u20131977  \n\n  * \u3010120\u2020Bus massacre\u3011\n  * \u3010121\u2020Black Thursday\u3011\n  * \u3010122\u2020Battle of the Hotels\u3011\n  * \u3010123\u2020ASALA insurgency\u3011\n  * \u3010124\u2020Black Saturday\u3011\n  * \u3010125\u2020Karantina massacre\u3011\n  * \u3010126\u2020Damour massa", "pub_date": null, "extra": null}], "original_query": null}, "command": "mclick", "args": ["[0, 1, 2, 4, 5, 6]"], "status": "finished", "is_complete": true, "message_type": null, "model_slug": "gpt-4o", "default_model_slug": "gpt-4o", "parent_id": "da533943-4428-4402-a6d2-faf447182b3c", "request_id": "8cb3ce3dab260e27-MXP", "timestamp_": "absolute"}, "recipient": "all", "channel": null}, "parent": "da533943-4428-4402-a6d2-faf447182b3c", "children": ["2a9beb18-44e9-47ee-a290-827c9f6871bf"]}, "2a9beb18-44e9-47ee-a290-827c9f6871bf": {"id": "2a9beb18-44e9-47ee-a290-827c9f6871bf", "message": {"id": "2a9beb18-44e9-47ee-a290-827c9f6871bf", "author": {"role": "tool", "name": "browser", "metadata": {}}, "create_time": 1727695089.716461, "update_time": null, "content": {"content_type": "tether_quote", "url": "https://www.history.com/this-day-in-history/beirut-barracks-blown-up", "domain": "www.history.com", "text": "\nIn 1975, a bloody civil war erupted in Lebanon, with Palestinian and leftist Muslim guerrillas battling militias of the Christian Phalange Party, the Maronite Christian community, and other groups. During the next few years, Syrian, Israeli, and United Nations interventions failed to resolve the factional fighting, and on August 20, 1982, a multinational force including 800 U.S. Marines was ordered to Beirut to help coordinate the Palestinian withdrawal.\n\nThe Marines left Lebanese territory on September 10 but returned in strengthened numbers on September 29, following the massacre of Palestinian refugees by a Christian militia. The next day, the first U.S. Marine to die during the mission was killed while defusing a bomb. Other Marines fell prey to snipers. On April 18, 1983, a suicide bomber driving a van devastated the U.S. embassy in Beirut, killing 63 people, including 17 Americans. Then, on October 23, a Lebanese terrorist plowed his bomb-laden truck through three guard posts, a barbed-wire fence, and into the lobby of the Marines Corps headquarters in Beirut, where he detonated a massive bomb, killing 241 marine, navy, and army personnel. The bomb, which was made of a sophisticated explosive enhanced by gas, had an explosive power equivalent to 18,000 pounds of dynamite. The identities of the embassy and barracks bombers were not determined, but they were suspected to be Shiite terrorists associated with Iran.\n\nAfter the barracks bombing, many questioned whether President \u301020\u2020Ronald Reagan\u3011 had a solid policy aim in Lebanon. Serious questions also arose over the quality of security in the American sector of war-torn Beirut. The U.S. peacekeeping force occupied an exposed area near the airport, but for political reasons the marine commander had not been allowed to maintain a completely secure perimeter before the attack. In a national address on October 23, President Reagan vowed to keep the marines in Lebanon, but just four months later he announced the end of the American role in the peacekeeping force. On February 26, 1984, the main force of marines left Lebanon, leaving just a small contingent to guard the U.S. embassy in Beirut.\n\nBy: \u301021\u2020History.com Editors\u3011\n\n\u301022\u2020HISTORY.com\u2020history.com\u3011 works with a wide range of writers and editors to create accurate and informative content. All articles are regularly reviewed and updated by the HISTORY.com team. Articles with the \u201cHISTORY.com Editors\u201d byline have been written or edited by the HISTORY.com editors, including \u301023\u2020Amanda Onion\u3011, \u301024\u2020Missy Sullivan\u3011, \u301025\u2020Matt Mullen\u3011 and Christian Zapata.\n\n* * *\n\n## Citation Information \n\nArticle Title \n    Beirut barracks blown up \n\nAuthor\n    \u301021\u2020History.com Editors\u3011\n\nWebsite Name \n    HISTORY \n\nURL\n    \u301026\u2020https://www.history.com/this-day-in-history/beirut-barracks-blown-up\u3011\n\nDate Accessed \n    September 28, 2024 \n\nPublisher \n    A&amp;E Television Networks \n\nLast Updated \n    July 28, 2019 \n\nOriginal Published Date \n    February 9, 2010 \n\n## Fact Check \n\nWe strive for accuracy and fairness. During the next few years, Syrian, Israeli, and United Nations interventions failed to resolve the factional fighting, and on August 20, 1982, a multinational force including 800 U.S. Marines was ordered to Beirut to help coordinate the Palestinian withdrawal.\n\nThe Marines left Lebanese territory on September 10 but returned in strengthened numbers on September 29, following the massacre of Palestinian refugees by a Christian militia. The next day, the first U.S. Marine to die during the mission was killed while defusing a bomb. Other Marines fell prey to snipers. On April 18, 1983, a suicide bomber driving a van devastated the U.S. embassy in Beirut, killing 63 people, including 17 Americans. Then, on October 23, a Lebanese terrorist plowed his bomb-laden truck through three guard posts, a barbed-wire fence, and into the lobby of the Marines Corps headquarters in Beirut, where he detonated a massive bomb, killing 241 marine, navy, and army personnel. The bomb, which was made of a sophisticated explosive enhanced by gas, had an explosive power equivalent to 18,000 pounds of dynamite. The U.S. peacekeeping force occupied an exposed area near the airport, but for political reasons the marine commander had not been allowed to maintain a completely secure perimeter before the attack. In a national address on October 23, President Reagan vowed to keep the marines in Lebanon, but just four months later he announced the end of the American role in the peacekeeping force. This deployment followed Israel&#x27;s 1982 invasion of Lebanon, which was aimed at targeting Palestinian groups but escalated into broader conflict. The U.S. forces were involved in several incidents, including the tragic 1983 bombing of the Marine barracks in Beirut, which killed 241 American servicemen\u301030\u2020source\u3011.\n\n2. **1983 U.S. Embassy Bombing**: Another significant attack during the U.S. presence in Lebanon was the 1983 bombing of the U.S. Embassy in Beirut, which resulted in the deaths of 63 people, including 17 Americans. This attack was part of the broader context of violence during the Lebanese Civil War\u301029\u2020source\u3011.\n\n3. **Israeli Actions**: Israel, a key U.S. ally, has conducted numerous air strikes and military operations in Lebanon over the years, especially targeting Hezbollah and other militant groups. These operations have included significant engagements during the 1982 Lebanon War, where Israeli forces reached Beirut, and during the 2006 Lebanon War\u301025\u2020source\u3011\u301028\u2020source\u3011.\n\nEach of these engagements has been part of complex geopolitical dynamics involving local factions, regional powers, and international forces. The motivations and consequences of these interventions have been widely debated and remain subjects of significant historical and political analysis."]}, "status": "finished_successfully", "end_turn": true, "weight": 1.0, "metadata": {"citations": [{"start_ix": 625, "end_ix": 636, "citation_format_type": "tether_og", "metadata": {"type": "webpage", "title": "Beirut barracks blown up", "url": "https://www.history.com/this-day-in-history/beirut-barracks-blown-up", "text": "\nIn 1975, a bloody civil war erupted in Lebanon, with Palestinian and leftist Muslim guerrillas battling militias of the Christian Phalange Party, the Maronite Christian community, and other groups. During the next few years, Syrian, Israeli, and United Nations interventions failed to resolve the factional fighting, and on August 20, 1982, a multinational force including 800 U.S. Marines was ordered to Beirut to help coordinate the Palestinian withdrawal.\n\nThe Marines left Lebanese territory on September 10 but returned in strengthened numbers on September 29, following the massacre of Palestinian refugees by a Christian militia. The next day, the first U.S. Marine to die during the mission was killed while defusing a bomb. Other Marines fell prey to snipers. On April 18, 1983, a suicide bomber driving a van devastated the U.S. embassy in Beirut, killing 63 people, including 17 Americans. Then, on October 23, a Lebanese terrorist plowed his bomb-laden truck through three guard posts, a barbed-wire fence, and into the lobby of the Marines Corps headquarters in Beirut, where he detonated a massive bomb, killing 241 marine, navy, and army personnel. The bomb, which was made of a sophisticated explosive enhanced by gas, had an explosive power equivalent to 18,000 pounds of dynamite. The identities of the embassy and barracks bombers were not determined, but they were suspected to be Shiite terrorists associated with Iran.\n\nAfter the barracks bombing, many questioned whether President \u301020\u2020Ronald Reagan\u3011 had a solid policy aim in Lebanon. Serious questions also arose over the quality of security in the American sector of war-torn Beirut. The U.S. peacekeeping force occupied an exposed area near the airport, but for political reasons the marine commander had not been allowed to maintain a completely secure perimeter before the attack. In a national address on October 23, President Reagan vowed to keep the marines in Lebanon, but just four months later he announced the end of the American role in the peacekeeping force. On February 26, 1984, the main force of marines left Lebanon, leaving just a small contingent to guard the U.S. embassy in Beirut.\n\nBy: \u301021\u2020History.com Editors\u3011\n\n\u301022\u2020HISTORY.com\u2020history.com\u3011 works with a wide range of writers and editors to create accurate and informative content. You can opt out at any time. You must be 16 years or older and a resident of the United States.\n\nMore details: \u301035\u2020Privacy Notice\u2020www.aenetworks.com\u3011 | \u301036\u2020Terms of Use\u2020www.aenetworks.com\u3011 | \u301037\u2020Contact Us\u2020support.history.com\u3011\n\n[Image 14][Image 15]\u301038\u20202002\u3011\n\n### \u301039\u2020Hostage crisis in Moscow theater\u3011\n\n\u301031\u2020European History\u3011[Image 16][Image 17]\u301040\u20201993\u3011\n\n### \u301041\u2020Toronto Blue Jay Joe Carter wins World Series with ninth\u2011inning home run\u3011\n\n\u301042\u2020", "pub_date": null, "extra": {"cited_message_idx": 30, "search_result_idx": null, "evidence_text": "source", "cloud_doc_url": null}}}, {"start_ix": 940, "end_ix": 951, "citation_format_type": "tether_og", "metadata": {"type": "webpage", "title": "1983 US embassy bombing in Beirut - Wikipedia", "url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1983_US_embassy_bombing_in_Beirut", "text": "\nThe next day, Ambassador Robert Dillon, who had narrowly escaped injury in the bombing, said: &quot;Paramount among the essential business is our work for the withdrawal of all foreign forces from Lebanon.&quot; It is only by securing Lebanese government control over the country &quot;that terrible tragedies like the one we experienced yesterday can be avoided in the future.&quot;[ 5 ]\n\nThe President of Lebanon, \u3010102\u2020Amine Gemayel\u3011, cabled President Reagan on April 18, saying, &quot;The Lebanese people and myself express our deepest condolences to the families of the U.S. victims. The cross of peace is the burden of the courageous.&quot;[ 5 ] Meanwhile, Lebanon asked the United States, France, and Italy to double the size of the peacekeeping force. As of March 16, it numbered about 4,800 troops, including some 1,200 US Marines, 1,400 Italian soldiers, 2,100 French paratroopers and 100 British soldiers. \n\n\u3010103\u2020Iran\u3011 denied any role in the attack. Foreign Minister, \u3010104\u2020Ali Akbar Velayati\u3011 said, &quot;We deny any involvement and we think this allegation is another propaganda plot against us.&quot;[ 7 ]\n\nOn April 19, Prime Minister \u3010105\u2020Menachem Begin\u3011 of Israel sent President Reagan a message of condolence for the embassy bombing. &quot;I write in the name of Israel when I express to you my deep shock at the terrible outrage which took the lives of so many of the American embassy in Beirut yesterday.&quot;[ 5 ] Defense Minister \u3010106\u2020Moshe Arens\u3011, was quoted by Israeli radio that he told the cabinet the attack &quot;justified Israel&#x27;s demands for security arrangements in Lebanon.&quot; Minister \u3010107\u2020Yitzhak Shamir\u3011 of Israel called the embassy bombing &quot;shocking&quot; but added that, &quot;In Lebanon nothing is surprising. I think the lesson is simple and understood. The security problems in Lebanon are still most serious, and terrorist organizations will continue to operate there, at times with great success.&quot;[ 5 ]\n\n## U.S. economic aid\n\n[\u3010108\u2020edit\u3011]\n\nThe \u3010109\u2020House Foreign Affairs Committee\u3011 April 19 voted to approve $251 million in additional economic and military aid for Lebanon, as requested by the administration. But it attached an amendment to the bill that would force the White House to seek approval for any expanded US military role. \n\nThe \u3010110\u2020Senate Foreign Relations Committee\u3011 followed suit April 20, approving the aid request but attaching an amendment that required the president to obtain congressional authorization for &quot;any substantial expansion in the number or role of US armed forces in Lebanon or for the creation of a new, expanded or extended multinational peacekeeping force in Lebanon.&quot; If Congress did not act jointly on such a request within 60 days, however, the increase would then take effect automatically. \n\nThe Senate amendment was sponsored as a compromise by the committee&#x27;s chairman, Republican \u3010111\u2020Charles H. Percy\u3011 of Illinois. It prevented a move by the committee&#x27;s ranking Democrat, \u3010112\u2020Claiborne Pell\u3011 of Rhode Island, to extend the 1973 \u3010113\u2020War Powers Resolution\u3011 to Lebanon. On April 20, Pell said he would have had the votes to apply the resolution to US Marines in Lebanon. The law limited presidential commitment of troops in hostile situations to a maximum of 90 days unless Congress specifically approved their use. \n\nDeputy Secretary of State \u3010114\u2020Kenneth W. Dam\u3011, in a letter to the committee, had argued forcefully against use of the War Powers Resolution. Dam said it would &quot;amount to a public finding that US forces will be exposed to imminent risk of involvement in hostilities&quot;, which &quot;could give entirely the wrong public impression&quot; of US expectations for Lebanon&#x27;s future. Several influential congressmen had been urging an end to the US military role in Lebanon. After the embassy bombing, April 19, Republican Senator \u3010115\u2020Barry Goldwater\u3011 of Arizona said, &quot;I think it&#x27;s high time we bring the boys home.&quot; \n\n## Aftermath\n\n[\u3010116\u2020edit\u3011]\n\n  * \u3010117\u2020v\u3011\n  * \u3010118\u2020t\u3011\n  * \u3010119\u2020e\u3011\n\n\u301069\u2020Lebanese Civil War\u3011  \n\nFirst phase: 1975\u20131977  \n\n  * \u3010120\u2020Bus massacre\u3011\n  * \u3010121\u2020Black Thursday\u3011\n  * \u3010122\u2020Battle of the Hotels\u3011\n  * \u3010123\u2020ASALA insurgency\u3011\n  * \u3010124\u2020Black Saturday\u3011\n  * \u3010125\u2020Karantina massacre\u3011\n  * \u3010126\u2020Damour massa", "pub_date": null, "extra": {"cited_message_idx": 29, "search_result_idx": null, "evidence_text": "source", "cloud_doc_url": null}}}, {"start_ix": 1299, "end_ix": 1310, "citation_format_type": "tether_og", "metadata": {"type": "webpage", "title": "1983 Beirut barracks bombings - Wikipedia", "url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1983_Beirut_barracks_bombings", "text": "\n    10 September 1982 \u2013 The PLO retreats from Beirut under MNF protection. Subsequently, the 32nd MAU is ordered out of Beirut by the President of the United States.\n\n    14 September 1982 \u2013 Lebanon&#x27;s President, Bachir Gemayel, is assassinated.\n\n    16 September to 18 September 1982 \u2013 The \u3010232\u2020Sabra and Shatila massacre\u3011 occurs.\n\n    19 September 1982 \u2013 The destroyer USS John Rodgers and nuclear cruiser USS Virginia, operating off the coast of Beirut, conduct a naval bombardment onto the town of Suk al Gharb, in the hills overlooking Beirut, in support of the Lebanese Army, after it is nearly overrun by Syrian-backed Druze militiamen and Palestinian guerrillas. Over 300 rounds of 5&quot; shells are fired to suppress the attack.[ 15 ]\n\n    20 September 1982 \u2013 The Beirut residence of the U.S. ambassador is shelled; for a second day US naval ships again conduct counter fire operations.[ 16 ]\n\n    21 September 1982 \u2013 Bachir Gemayel&#x27;s brother, \u3010280\u2020Amine Gemayel\u3011, is elected to be Lebanon&#x27;s president.\n\n    29 September 1982 \u2013 The 32nd \u3010279\u2020MAU\u3011 is redeployed to Beirut (primarily at the BIA) rejoining 2,200 French and Italian MNF troops already in place.\n\n    30 October 1982 \u2013 The 32nd MAU is relieved by the 24th MAU.\n\n    15 February 1983 \u2013 The 32nd MAU, redesignated as the 22nd MAU, returns to Lebanon to relieve the 24th MAU.\n\n    18 April 1983 \u2013 The \u3010281\u2020U.S. Embassy bombing\u3011 in Beirut kills 63, of whom 17 are Americans.\n\n    17 May 1983 \u2013 The \u3010282\u2020May 17 Agreement\u3011 is signed.\n\n    30 May 1983 \u2013 The 24th MAU relieves the 22nd MAU.[ 17 ]\n\n### Mission\n\n[\u3010283\u2020edit\u3011]\n\n[Image 4]The USMC barracks in Beirut\n\nOn June 6, 1982, the \u3010284\u2020Israel Defense Forces\u3011 (IDF) initiated Operation &quot;Peace for Galilee&quot; and invaded Lebanon in order to create a 40 km buffer zone between the PLO and \u3010285\u2020Syrian\u3011 forces in Lebanon and Israel.[ 18 ][ 19 ][ 20 ] The Israeli invasion was tacitly approved by the U.S., and the U.S. provided overt military support to Israel in the form of arms and materiel.[ 21 ] The U.S.&#x27; support for Israel&#x27;s invasion of Lebanon taken in conjunction with U.S. support for Lebanese President \u3010278\u2020Bachir Gemayel\u3011 and the \u3010286\u2020Lebanese Armed Forces\u3011 (LAF) alienated many.[ 22 ]\n\nBachir Gemayel was the legally elected president, but he was a partisan \u3010287\u2020Maronite Christian\u3011 and covert associate of Israel.[ 23 ] These factors served to disaffect the \u3010288\u2020Lebanese Muslim\u3011 and \u3010289\u2020Druze\u3011 communities. This animosity was made worse by the \u3010290\u2020Phalangist\u3011, a right-wing, largely Maronite-Lebanese militia force closely associated with President Gemayel. The Phalangist militia was responsible for multiple, bloody attacks against the Muslim and Druze communities in Lebanon and for the 1982 atrocities committed in the PLO refugee camps, \u3010232\u2020Sabra and Shatila\u3011 by \u3010291\u2020Lebanese Forces\u3011 (LF), while the IDF provided security and looked on.[ 24 ][ 25 ]\n\nThe Phalangist militia&#x27;s attacks on Sabra and Shatila were purportedly a response to the September 14, 1982, assassination of President-elect Bachir Gemayel.[ 24 ][ 26 ][ 27 ] \u3010280\u2020Amine Gemayel\u3011, Bachir&#x27;s brother, succeeded Bachir as the elected president of Lebanon, and Amine continued to represent and advance Maronite interests. \n\nAll of this, according to British foreign correspondent \u3010292\u2020Robert Fisk\u3011, served to generate ill will against the MNF among Lebanese Muslims and especially among the \u3010293\u2020Shiites\u3011 living in the slums of West Beirut. Lebanese Muslims believed the MNF, and the Americans in particular, were unfairly siding with the Maronite Christians in their attempt to dominate Lebanon.[ 28 ][ 29 ][ 30 ] As a result, this led to artillery, mortar, and small arms fire being directed at MNF peacekeepers by Muslim factions. Operating under the \u3010294\u2020peacetime\u3011 \u3010295\u2020rules of engagement\u3011, MNF peacekeepers \u2013 primarily U.S. and French forces \u2013 used ", "pub_date": null, "extra": {"cited_message_idx": 25, "search_result_idx": null, "evidence_text": "source", "cloud_doc_url": null}}}, {"start_ix": 1310, "end_ix": 1321, "citation_format_type": "tether_og", "metadata": {"type": "webpage", "title": "Lebanese Civil War | History, &amp; Significance | Britannica", "url": "https://www.britannica.com/event/Lebanese-Civil-War", "text": "(Show\u00a0more)\n\nMajor Events: \n    \u301085\u20201983 Beirut barracks bombings\u3011\n(Show\u00a0more)\n\nKey People: \n    \u301086\u2020Michel Aoun\u3011\n    \u301087\u2020Bashir Gemayel\u3011\n    \u301088\u2020Pierre Gemayel\u3011\n(Show\u00a0more)\n\n\u301057\u2020 See all related content \u2192\u3011 \n\nAsk the Chatbot a Question  Ask the Chatbot a Question \n\nLebanese Civil War, civil conflict (1975\u201390) in \u301083\u2020Lebanon\u3011 emanating from the deterioration of the Lebanese state and the coalescence of militias that provided security where the state could not. These militias formed largely along communal lines: the Lebanese Front (LF), led by the Phalangists (or Phalange), represented \u301089\u2020Maronite\u3011 Christian clans whose leaders had dominated the traditional elite class of the country\u2019s sociopolitical fabric; the Lebanese National Movement (LNM), a coalition of \u301090\u2020secular\u2020www.merriam-webster.com\u3011 leftists and \u301091\u2020Sunni\u3011 Muslims sympathetic to \u301092\u2020Arab nationalism\u3011; the Amal (\u201cHope,\u201d also an \u301093\u2020acronym\u2020www.merriam-webster.com\u3011 for Afw\u0101j al-Muq\u0101wamah al-Lubn\u0101niyyah [Lebanese Resistance Detachments]) movement, \u301094\u2020comprising\u2020www.merriam-webster.com\u3011 \u301095\u2020Shi\u02bfi\u3011 populists; and the \u301084\u2020Palestine Liberation Organization\u3011 (PLO), which represented Lebanon\u2019s large Palestinian refugee population. Other participants in the \u301096\u2020war\u3011 included \u301097\u2020Syria\u3011, \u301098\u2020Israel\u3011, and splintered \u301099\u2020contingents\u2020www.merriam-webster.com\u3011 of the Lebanese Army.\n\n## Background\n\nThe causes of the war were multifaceted and deeply rooted but can be generalized as a growing crisis of insecurity. After he played a key role as commander of the army in resolving the crisis of a 1958 rebellion, the newly elected president \u3010100\u2020Fuad Chehab\u3011 made a valiant attempt to address the disproportionate development of the country and to centralize the state\u2019s security apparatus. By the late 1960s, however, the development program he initiated proved politically unsatisfactory and had become a destabilizing force. The strengthened security apparatus, meanwhile, gained a reputation for suppression and corruption. The situation grew more \u3010101\u2020precarious\u3011 as the government negotiated the presence and operation of PLO guerrillas inside Lebanon\u2019s Palestinian refugee camps, which had attracted Israeli raids on Lebanon, most notably on the airport in \u3010102\u2020Beirut\u3011 in 1968. As the state proved increasingly unable to maintain a monopoly of force, patronage networks, both existing and new, began arming and organizing their own security.\n\n\u301061\u2020 Britannica Quiz A History of War \u3011\n\nOn August 17, 1970, \u3010103\u2020Suleiman Franjieh\u3011, leader of a powerful Maronite clan from northern Lebanon who sought to undo the reform program initiated by Chehab, was elected president by one vote after three rounds of balloting. His presidency, polarizing and corrupt, alienated Muslims and Christians alike, and his government proved unable to maintain the state\u2019s dominance over the growing and diffuse militias of the PLO. The Phalangist militia of the rival Maronite \u3010104\u2020Gemayel clan\u3011 began taking matters into its own hands by confronting the Palestinian militias directly.\n\n## Progression of the war\n\nThe beginning of the civil war is typically dated to April 13, 1975, when the Phalangists attacked a bus taking Palestinians to a refugee camp at \u3010105\u2020Tall al-Za\u02bftar\u3011, Lebanon. The attack escalated an \u3010106\u2020intermittent\u2020www.merriam-webster.com\u3011 cycle of violence into a more general battle between the Phalangists and the LNM, whose coalition of Lebanese leftists and Muslims supported the PLO\u2019s cause.\n\nIn the months that followed, the general destruction of the central market area of Beirut was marked by the emergence of a \u201cgreen line\u201d between Muslim West Beirut and Christian East Beirut, which persisted until the end of the civil war in 1990, with each side under the control of its respective militias.\n\nAs Franjieh\u2019s term came to an end, and with Lebanon\u2019s army splintered, he asked Syria to intervene to prevent the country from disintegrating into multiple states. Despite its earlier support for the PLO in the south, Syria launched a large-scale intervention to \u3010107\u2020redress\u3011 the emerging imbalance of power in favour of the Christians in the north. Syria\u2019s intervention sparked a more active Israeli involvement as well, in which Israel armed and financed Christian militias in the south of the country, whom Israelis looked upon as their", "pub_date": null, "extra": {"cited_message_idx": 28, "search_result_idx": null, "evidence_text": "source", "cloud_doc_url": null}}}], "content_references": [{"matched_text": "\u301030\u2020source\u3011", "start_idx": 625, "end_idx": 636, "alt": null, "type": "webpage_extended", "title": "Beirut barracks blown up", "url": "https://www.history.com/this-day-in-history/beirut-barracks-blown-up", "pub_date": null, "snippet": "\nIn 1975, a bloody civil war erupted in Lebanon, with Palestinian and leftist Muslim guerrillas battling militias of the Christian Phalange Party, the Maronite Christian community, and other groups. During the next few years, Syrian, Israeli, and United Nations interventions failed to resolve the factional fighting, and on August 20, 1982, a multinational force including 800 U.S. Marines was ordered to Beirut to help coordinate the Palestinian withdrawal.\n\nThe Marines left Lebanese territory on September 10 but returned in strengthened numbers on September 29, following the massacre of Palestinian refugees by a Christian militia. The next day, the first U.S. Marine to die during the mission was killed while defusing a bomb. Other Marines fell prey to snipers. On April 18, 1983, a suicide bomber driving a van devastated the U.S. embassy in Beirut, killing 63 people, including 17 Americans. Then, on October 23, a Lebanese terrorist plowed his bomb-laden truck through three guard posts, a barbed-wire fence, and into the lobby of the Marines Corps headquarters in Beirut, where he detonated a massive bomb, killing 241 marine, navy, and army personnel. The bomb, which was made of a sophisticated explosive enhanced by gas, had an explosive power equivalent to 18,000 pounds of dynamite. The identities of the embassy and barracks bombers were not determined, but they were suspected to be Shiite terrorists associated with Iran.\n\nAfter the barracks bombing, many questioned whether President \u301020\u2020Ronald Reagan\u3011 had a solid policy aim in Lebanon. Serious questions also arose over the quality of security in the American sector of war-torn Beirut. The U.S. peacekeeping force occupied an exposed area near the airport, but for political reasons the marine commander had not been allowed to maintain a completely secure perimeter before the attack. In a national address on October 23, President Reagan vowed to keep the marines in Lebanon, but just four months later he announced the end of the American role in the peacekeeping force. On February 26, 1984, the main force of marines left Lebanon, leaving just a small contingent to guard the U.S. embassy in Beirut.\n\nBy: \u301021\u2020History.com Editors\u3011\n\n\u301022\u2020HISTORY.com\u2020history.com\u3011 works with a wide range of writers and editors to create accurate and informative content. All articles are regularly reviewed and updated by the HISTORY.com team. Articles with the \u201cHISTORY.com Editors\u201d byline have been written or edited by the HISTORY.com editors, including \u301023\u2020Amanda Onion\u3011, \u301024\u2020Missy Sullivan\u3011, \u301025\u2020Matt Mullen\u3011 and Christian Zapata.\n\n* * *\n\n## Citation Information \n\nArticle Title \n    Beirut barracks blown up \n\nAuthor\n    \u301021\u2020History.com Editors\u3011\n\nWebsite Name \n    HISTORY \n\nURL\n    \u301026\u2020https://www.history.com/this-day-in-history/beirut-barracks-blown-up\u3011\n\nDate Accessed \n    September 28, 2024 \n\nPublisher \n    A&amp;E Television Networks \n\nLast Updated \n    July 28, 2019 \n\nOriginal Published Date \n    February 9, 2010 \n\n## Fact Check \n\nWe strive for accuracy and fairness. You must be 16 years or older and a resident of the United States.\n\nMore details: \u301035\u2020Privacy Notice\u2020www.aenetworks.com\u3011 | \u301036\u2020Terms of Use\u2020www.aenetworks.com\u3011 | \u301037\u2020Contact Us\u2020support.history.com\u3011\n\n[Image 14][Image 15]\u301038\u20202002\u3011\n\n### \u301039\u2020Hostage crisis in Moscow theater\u3011\n\n\u301031\u2020European History\u3011[Image 16][Image 17]\u301040\u20201993\u3011\n\n### \u301041\u2020Toronto Blue Jay Joe Carter wins World Series with ninth\u2011inning home run\u3011\n\n\u301042\u2020"}, {"matched_text": "\u301029\u2020source\u3011", "start_idx": 940, "end_idx": 951, "alt": null, "type": "webpage_extended", "title": "1983 US embassy bombing in Beirut - Wikipedia", "url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1983_US_embassy_bombing_in_Beirut", "pub_date": null, "snippet": "\nThe next day, Ambassador Robert Dillon, who had narrowly escaped injury in the bombing, said: &quot;Paramount among the essential business is our work for the withdrawal of all foreign forces from Lebanon.&quot; It is only by securing Lebanese government control over the country &quot;that terrible tragedies like the one we experienced yesterday can be avoided in the future.&quot;[ 5 ]\n\nThe President of Lebanon, \u3010102\u2020Amine Gemayel\u3011, cabled President Reagan on April 18, saying, &quot;The Lebanese people and myself express our deepest condolences to the families of the U.S. victims. The cross of peace is the burden of the courageous.&quot;[ 5 ] Meanwhile, Lebanon asked the United States, France, and Italy to double the size of the peacekeeping force. As of March 16, it numbered about 4,800 troops, including some 1,200 US Marines, 1,400 Italian soldiers, 2,100 French paratroopers and 100 British soldiers. \n\n\u3010103\u2020Iran\u3011 denied any role in the attack. Foreign Minister, \u3010104\u2020Ali Akbar Velayati\u3011 said, &quot;We deny any involvement and we think this allegation is another propaganda plot against us.&quot;[ 7 ]\n\nOn April 19, Prime Minister \u3010105\u2020Menachem Begin\u3011 of Israel sent President Reagan a message of condolence for the embassy bombing. &quot;I write in the name of Israel when I express to you my deep shock at the terrible outrage which took the lives of so many of the American embassy in Beirut yesterday.&quot;[ 5 ] Defense Minister \u3010106\u2020Moshe Arens\u3011, was quoted by Israeli radio that he told the cabinet the attack &quot;justified Israel&#x27;s demands for security arrangements in Lebanon.&quot; Minister \u3010107\u2020Yitzhak Shamir\u3011 of Israel called the embassy bombing &quot;shocking&quot; but added that, &quot;In Lebanon nothing is surprising. I think the lesson is simple and understood. The security problems in Lebanon are still most serious, and terrorist organizations will continue to operate there, at times with great success.&quot;[ 5 ]\n\n## U.S. economic aid\n\n[\u3010108\u2020edit\u3011]\n\nThe \u3010109\u2020House Foreign Affairs Committee\u3011 April 19 voted to approve $251 million in additional economic and military aid for Lebanon, as requested by the administration. But it attached an amendment to the bill that would force the White House to seek approval for any expanded US military role. \n\nThe \u3010110\u2020Senate Foreign Relations Committee\u3011 followed suit April 20, approving the aid request but attaching an amendment that required the president to obtain congressional authorization for &quot;any substantial expansion in the number or role of US armed forces in Lebanon or for the creation of a new, expanded or extended multinational peacekeeping force in Lebanon.&quot; If Congress did not act jointly on such a request within 60 days, however, the increase would then take effect automatically. \n\nThe Senate amendment was sponsored as a compromise by the committee&#x27;s chairman, Republican \u3010111\u2020Charles H. Percy\u3011 of Illinois. It prevented a move by the committee&#x27;s ranking Democrat, \u3010112\u2020Claiborne Pell\u3011 of Rhode Island, to extend the 1973 \u3010113\u2020War Powers Resolution\u3011 to Lebanon. On April 20, Pell said he would have had the votes to apply the resolution to US Marines in Lebanon. The law limited presidential commitment of troops in hostile situations to a maximum of 90 days unless Congress specifically approved their use. \n\nDeputy Secretary of State \u3010114\u2020Kenneth W. Dam\u3011, in a letter to the committee, had argued forcefully against use of the War Powers Resolution. Dam said it would &quot;amount to a public finding that US forces will be exposed to imminent risk of involvement in hostilities&quot;, which &quot;could give entirely the wrong public impression&quot; of US expectations for Lebanon&#x27;s future. Several influential congressmen had been urging an end to the US military role in Lebanon. After the embassy bombing, April 19, Republican Senator \u3010115\u2020Barry Goldwater\u3011 of Arizona said, &quot;I think it&#x27;s high time we bring the boys home.&quot; \n\n## Aftermath\n\n[\u3010116\u2020edit\u3011]\n\n  * \u3010117\u2020v\u3011\n  * \u3010118\u2020t\u3011\n  * \u3010119\u2020e\u3011\n\n\u301069\u2020Lebanese Civil War\u3011  \n\nFirst phase: 1975\u20131977  \n\n  * \u3010120\u2020Bus massacre\u3011\n  * \u3010121\u2020Black Thursday\u3011\n  * \u3010122\u2020Battle of the Hotels\u3011\n  * \u3010123\u2020ASALA insurgency\u3011\n  * \u3010124\u2020Black Saturday\u3011\n  * \u3010125\u2020Karantina massacre\u3011\n  * \u3010126\u2020Damour massa"}, {"matched_text": "\u301025\u2020source\u3011", "start_idx": 1299, "end_idx": 1310, "alt": null, "type": "webpage_extended", "title": "1983 Beirut barracks bombings - Wikipedia", "url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1983_Beirut_barracks_bombings", "pub_date": null, "snippet": "\n    10 September 1982 \u2013 The PLO retreats from Beirut under MNF protection. and invaded Lebanon in order to create a 40 km buffer zone between the PLO and \u3010285\u2020Syrian\u3011 forces in Lebanon and Israel.[ 18 ][ 19 ][ 20 ] The Israeli invasion was tacitly approved by the U.S., and the U.S. provided overt military support to Israel in the form of arms and materiel.[ 21 ] The U.S.&#x27; support for Israel&#x27;s invasion of Lebanon taken in conjunction with U.S. support for Lebanese President \u3010278\u2020Bachir Gemayel\u3011 and the \u3010286\u2020Lebanese Armed Forces\u3011 (LAF) alienated many.[ 22 ]\n\nBachir Gemayel was the legally elected president, but he was a partisan \u3010287\u2020Maronite Christian\u3011 and covert associate of Israel.[ 23 ] These factors served to disaffect the \u3010288\u2020Lebanese Muslim\u3011 and \u3010289\u2020Druze\u3011 communities. This animosity was made worse by the \u3010290\u2020Phalangist\u3011, a right-wing, largely Maronite-Lebanese militia force closely associated with President Gemayel. The Phalangist militia was responsible for multiple, bloody attacks against the Muslim and Druze communities in Lebanon and for the 1982 atrocities committed in the PLO refugee camps, \u3010232\u2020Sabra and Shatila\u3011 by \u3010291\u2020Lebanese Forces\u3011 (LF), while the IDF provided security and looked on.[ 24 ][ 25 ]\n\nThe Phalangist militia&#x27;s attacks on Sabra and Shatila were purportedly a response to the September 14, 1982, assassination of President-elect Bachir Gemayel.[ 24 ][ 26 ][ 27 ] \u3010280\u2020Amine Gemayel\u3011, Bachir&#x27;s brother, succeeded Bachir as the elected president of Lebanon, and Amine continued to represent and advance Maronite interests. \n\nAll of this, according to British foreign correspondent \u3010292\u2020Robert Fisk\u3011, served to generate ill will against the MNF among Lebanese Muslims and especially among the \u3010293\u2020Shiites\u3011 living in the slums of West Beirut. Lebanese Muslims believed the MNF, and the Americans in particular, were unfairly siding with the Maronite Christians in their attempt to dominate Lebanon.[ 28 ][ 29 ][ 30 ] As a result, this led to artillery, mortar, and small arms fire being directed at MNF peacekeepers by Muslim factions. Operating under the \u3010294\u2020peacetime\u3011 \u3010295\u2020rules of engagement\u3011, MNF peacekeepers \u2013 primarily U.S. and French forces \u2013 used "}, {"matched_text": "\u301028\u2020source\u3011", "start_idx": 1310, "end_idx": 1321, "alt": null, "type": "webpage_extended", "title": "Lebanese Civil War | History, &amp; Significance | Britannica", "url": "https://www.britannica.com/event/Lebanese-Civil-War", "pub_date": null, "snippet": "(Show\u00a0more)\n\nMajor Events: \n    \u301085\u20201983 Beirut barracks bombings\u3011\n(Show\u00a0more)\n\nKey People: \n    \u301086\u2020Michel Aoun\u3011\n    \u301087\u2020Bashir Gemayel\u3011\n    \u301088\u2020Pierre Gemayel\u3011\n(Show\u00a0more)\n\n\u301057\u2020 See all related content \u2192\u3011 \n\nAsk the Chatbot a Question  Ask the Chatbot a Question \n\nLebanese Civil War, civil conflict (1975\u201390) in \u301083\u2020Lebanon\u3011 emanating from the deterioration of the Lebanese state and the coalescence of militias that provided security where the state could not. These militias formed largely along communal lines: the Lebanese Front (LF), led by the Phalangists (or Phalange), represented \u301089\u2020Maronite\u3011 Christian clans whose leaders had dominated the traditional elite class of the country\u2019s sociopolitical fabric; the Lebanese National Movement (LNM), a coalition of \u301090\u2020secular\u2020www.merriam-webster.com\u3011 leftists and \u301091\u2020Sunni\u3011 Muslims sympathetic to \u301092\u2020Arab nationalism\u3011; the Amal (\u201cHope,\u201d also an \u301093\u2020acronym\u2020www.merriam-webster.com\u3011 for Afw\u0101j al-Muq\u0101wamah al-Lubn\u0101niyyah [Lebanese Resistance Detachments]) movement, \u301094\u2020comprising\u2020www.merriam-webster.com\u3011 \u301095\u2020Shi\u02bfi\u3011 populists; and the \u301084\u2020Palestine Liberation Organization\u3011 (PLO), which represented Lebanon\u2019s large Palestinian refugee population. Other participants in the \u301096\u2020war\u3011 included \u301097\u2020Syria\u3011, \u301098\u2020Israel\u3011, and splintered \u301099\u2020contingents\u2020www.merriam-webster.com\u3011 of the Lebanese Army.\n\n## Background\n\nThe causes of the war were multifaceted and deeply rooted but can be generalized as a growing crisis of insecurity. After he played a key role as commander of the army in resolving the crisis of a 1958 rebellion, the newly elected president \u3010100\u2020Fuad Chehab\u3011 made a valiant attempt to address the disproportionate development of the country and to centralize the state\u2019s security apparatus. By the late 1960s, however, the development program he initiated proved politically unsatisfactory and had become a destabilizing force. The strengthened security apparatus, meanwhile, gained a reputation for suppression and corruption. The situation grew more \u3010101\u2020precarious\u3011 as the government negotiated the presence and operation of PLO guerrillas inside Lebanon\u2019s Palestinian refugee camps, which had attracted Israeli raids on Lebanon, most notably on the airport in \u3010102\u2020Beirut\u3011 in 1968. As the state proved increasingly unable to maintain a monopoly of force, patronage networks, both existing and new, began arming and organizing their own security.\n\n\u301061\u2020 Britannica Quiz A History of War \u3011\n\nOn August 17, 1970, \u3010103\u2020Suleiman Franjieh\u3011, leader of a powerful Maronite clan from northern Lebanon who sought to undo the reform program initiated by Chehab, was elected president by one vote after three rounds of balloting. His presidency, polarizing and corrupt, alienated Muslims and Christians alike, and his government proved unable to maintain the state\u2019s dominance over the growing and diffuse militias of the PLO. The Phalangist militia of the rival Maronite \u3010104\u2020Gemayel clan\u3011 began taking matters into its own hands by confronting the Palestinian militias directly.\n\n## Progression of the war\n\nThe beginning of the civil war is typically dated to April 13, 1975, when the Phalangists attacked a bus taking Palestinians to a refugee camp at \u3010105\u2020Tall al-Za\u02bftar\u3011, Lebanon. The attack escalated an \u3010106\u2020intermittent\u2020www.merriam-webster.com\u3011 cycle of violence into a more general battle between the Phalangists and the LNM, whose coalition of Lebanese leftists and Muslims supported the PLO\u2019s cause.\n\nIn the months that followed, the general destruction of the central market area of Beirut was marked by the emergence of a \u201cgreen line\u201d between Muslim West Beirut and Christian East Beirut, which persisted until the end of the civil war in 1990, with each side under the control of its respective militias.\n\nAs Franjieh\u2019s term came to an end, and with Lebanon\u2019s army splintered, he asked Syria to intervene to prevent the country from disintegrating into multiple states. Despite its earlier support for the PLO in the south, Syria launched a large-scale intervention to \u3010107\u2020redress\u3011 the emerging imbalance of power in favour of the Christians in the north. Syria\u2019s intervention sparked a more active Israeli involvement as well, in which Israel armed and financed Christian militias in the south of the country, whom Israelis looked upon as their"}], "gizmo_id": null, "message_type": null, "model_slug": "gpt-4o", "default_model_slug": "gpt-4o", "pad": "AAAA", "parent_id": "2a9beb18-44e9-47ee-a290-827c9f6871bf", "finish_details": {"type": "stop", "stop_tokens": [100260]}, "is_complete": true, "request_id": "8cb3ce3dab260e27-MXP", "timestamp_": "absolute"}, "recipient": "all", "channel": null}, "parent": "2a9beb18-44e9-47ee-a290-827c9f6871bf", "children": ["3cea2bc2-9168-4618-8e79-f4841f0533d2"]}, "3cea2bc2-9168-4618-8e79-f4841f0533d2": {"id": "3cea2bc2-9168-4618-8e79-f4841f0533d2", "message": {"id": "3cea2bc2-9168-4618-8e79-f4841f0533d2", "author": {"role": "user", "name": null, "metadata": {}}, "create_time": 1727695171.385269, "update_time": null, "content": {"content_type": "text", "parts": ["Can you make me a picture of a map clearly defining where lebanon, yemen, iran and palestine are in realation to israel?"]}, "status": "finished_successfully", "end_turn": null, "weight": 1.0, "metadata": {"request_id": "8cb3d182e8c95232-MXP", "message_source": null, "timestamp_": "absolute", "message_type": null}, "recipient": "all", "channel": null}, "parent": "69720d05-6256-42c8-81dd-305f0d6c4098", "children": ["6c2502f9-7a03-40c8-b093-474c1b4081cd"]}, "6c2502f9-7a03-40c8-b093-474c1b4081cd": {"id": "6c2502f9-7a03-40c8-b093-474c1b4081cd", "message": {"id": "6c2502f9-7a03-40c8-b093-474c1b4081cd", "author": {"role": "assistant", "name": null, "metadata": {}}, "create_time": 1727695209.896711, "update_time": null, "content": {"content_type": "text", "parts": ["{&quot;prompt&quot;:&quot;A detailed political map showcasing the Middle East, highlighting Lebanon, Yemen, Iran, Palestine, and Israel.
