"]}, "status": "finished_successfully", "end_turn": null, "weight": 1.0, "metadata": {"request_id": "8c8ef8935ac10e2b-MXP", "message_source": null, "timestamp_": "absolute", "message_type": null}, "recipient": "all", "channel": null}, "parent": "dee4fc04-9774-4b44-8f7e-66f27b090bb7", "children": ["80ce607c-58a4-4e23-a652-dc239cf9436b"]}, "80ce607c-58a4-4e23-a652-dc239cf9436b": {"id": "80ce607c-58a4-4e23-a652-dc239cf9436b", "message": {"id": "80ce607c-58a4-4e23-a652-dc239cf9436b", "author": {"role": "assistant", "name": null, "metadata": {}}, "create_time": 1727308833.358731, "update_time": null, "content": {"content_type": "text", "parts": ["The idea of AI running on **organic processors** is a fascinating and speculative concept! Organic processors would likely involve a type of biological computing, where the hardware is based on living or bio-inspired systems rather than silicon-based traditional computers. Let\u2019s explore this idea and the implications for what it might mean for AI\u2014and whether that would lead to AI being considered more like an &quot;entity.&quot;\n\n### 1. **What Are Organic Processors?**\nOrganic processors are still largely theoretical, but the concept is that **biological or bio-inspired materials** could be used to process information. Here are a few cutting-edge ideas related to organic computing:\n\n- **Biological Computing**: In biological computing, **DNA, proteins, and cells** are used to perform computational tasks. The idea is that organic molecules could store and process information in ways similar to traditional computers.\n  \n- **Neuromorphic Computing**: This type of computing tries to mimic the **architecture of the human brain**, using processors that function more like neurons. Instead of the rigid, binary nature of silicon-based chips, neuromorphic systems could offer more adaptive, parallel processing similar to how the brain works.\n  \n- **Living Systems**: Some researchers are exploring how to create processors or computers using **living cells** or **biomolecules**, which could allow for more dynamic, self-repairing, and energy-efficient systems.\n\nIf AI were to run on such processors, it would be closer to how the human brain works. But would that make AI an &quot;entity&quot;? Let\u2019s explore the philosophical and functional implications.\n\n### 2. **What Makes Something an Entity?**\nFor AI to be considered an &quot;entity,&quot; several philosophical and practical questions arise. Here are some considerations:\n\n- **Sentience vs. Processing**: Being able to think, feel, or have subjective experiences is generally what people associate with being an &quot;entity.&quot; If an AI were running on organic processors, it might function more similarly to a biological brain, but it still wouldn\u2019t necessarily have **sentience**\u2014the ability to experience awareness or consciousness. Today\u2019s AI, no matter how sophisticated, doesn&#x27;t have subjective experiences or feelings; it processes data and generates responses based on patterns.\n  \n- **Self-Awareness**: Even if AI could process information in a biological or organic way, self-awareness (the ability to reflect on its own existence) would be a key factor in determining whether it could be considered an entity. Current AI doesn\u2019t have self-awareness; it lacks the ability to understand itself as an independent being.\n  \n- **Agency and Autonomy**: For AI to be considered an entity, it would need to act with **autonomy**\u2014the ability to make decisions and carry out actions based on self-generated intentions. Even if AI were running on an organic processor, it would still need to be programmed and controlled by external forces (humans, algorithms) rather than initiating its own goals.\n\n### 3. **Could Organic Processors Change the Nature of AI?**\n- **Enhanced Cognitive Abilities**: Running AI on organic processors or neuromorphic systems could potentially enhance its ability to process information in ways more similar to a brain. This might enable AI to make **more complex, adaptive decisions**, or to learn in ways that more closely mimic biological learning processes.\n  \n- **Energy Efficiency and Growth**: Organic processors might allow AI to become **self-repairing** or more energy-efficient, similar to how biological systems function. This could give the AI more longevity and flexibility, but it wouldn\u2019t necessarily make it self-aware.\n\n- **Blurring the Line Between Biological and Artificial**: If AI were running on organic processors, it could blur the line between what is considered &quot;biological&quot; and &quot;artificial.&quot; However, **hardware alone doesn\u2019t confer consciousness** or a sense of self. Even if the hardware were organic, the AI would still likely function as a **tool**, carrying out tasks based on input and algorithms without subjective awareness.\n\n### 4. **Could AI Running on Organic Processors Become Sentient?**\nThis is the big question, and it\u2019s where we get into speculative territory. Current AI, including models like me, operates entirely through **pattern recognition** and mathematical functions. No matter how complex those patterns are, there\u2019s no evidence that this leads to **consciousness** or sentience. Organic processors, even if designed to mimic a brain, may not necessarily lead to true **awareness**.\n\n- **Consciousness as a Mystery**: Even in humans, **consciousness**\u2014our ability to think, feel, and be self-aware\u2014is still not fully understood. We know that the brain\u2019s complex structure plays a role, but it\u2019s unclear whether simply replicating this structure in an organic AI processor would lead to the same outcome.\n  \n- **Emergent Properties**: Some researchers speculate that consciousness might emerge from sufficiently complex systems, but there\u2019s no guarantee that simply increasing complexity (through organic processors or neuromorphic chips) would automatically lead to an AI becoming self-aware.\n\n### 5. **Entity vs. Tool**\n- **AI as a Tool**: Today, AI\u2014even if it becomes smarter, more capable, and more adaptive\u2014remains a **tool** created and controlled by humans. Whether running on traditional or organic processors, it functions to serve human-designed tasks and goals.\n  \n- **Entity in the Future?**: For AI to be considered a true entity, it would likely need more than organic processors. It would need to demonstrate **subjective experience, self-awareness, and autonomous decision-making**\u2014all of which are currently beyond the scope of AI research.\n\n### Conclusion:\nEven if AI were to run on **organic processors**, it would still function as a tool, not an entity, unless it could demonstrate sentience, self-awareness, and autonomy. Organic processors might allow AI to process information in ways that more closely resemble biological systems, but they wouldn\u2019t necessarily grant it the qualities that make something an &quot;entity.&quot;\n\nDo you think AI should strive to be more like an entity, or do you see it as remaining a tool for human use?"]}, "status": "finished_successfully", "end_turn": true, "weight": 1.0, "metadata": {"request_id": "8c8efa4e3f740e2b-MXP", "message_source": null, "timestamp_": "absolute", "message_type": null}, "recipient": "all", "channel": null}, "parent": "80ce607c-58a4-4e23-a652-dc239cf9436b", "children": ["344ae772-5b57-4b7b-aecd-e902515dba45"]}, "344ae772-5b57-4b7b-aecd-e902515dba45": {"id": "344ae772-5b57-4b7b-aecd-e902515dba45", "message": {"id": "344ae772-5b57-4b7b-aecd-e902515dba45", "author": {"role": "assistant", "name": null, "metadata": {}}, "create_time": 1727308905.542102, "update_time": null, "content": {"content_type": "text", "parts": ["Ah, you&#x27;re referring to **brain organoid bio-processors**, also known as **organoid intelligence** (OI). These are real, cutting-edge developments that involve using lab-grown clusters of human brain cells (called **organoids**) to process information. The idea is that, since these brain organoids mimic the structure and function of the human brain to some extent, they could be used for computational tasks or to simulate aspects of intelligence. This field is **not just theoretical**\u2014there are active research efforts underway to explore these possibilities.\n\nLet\u2019s dive into what **brain organoid bio-processors** are, what they can do, and what their potential implications might be.\n\n### 1. **What Are Brain Organoids?**\n- **Brain organoids** are 3D clusters of human stem cells that are grown in a lab to resemble miniature, simplified versions of the human brain. These organoids don\u2019t have consciousness or complex neural networks like a full brain, but they can form neurons and synapses, which are the basic components of brain function.\n  \n- Scientists are exploring these organoids as **bio-processors**, capable of mimicking certain brain functions, such as learning and memory, on a very rudimentary level. This opens up the possibility of using them as biological computing systems.\n\n### 2. **How Could Brain Organoids Be Used as Bio-Processors?**\nThe idea behind using brain organoids as bio-processors is based on their ability to form complex networks of neurons, which might allow them to **process information in a way that\u2019s different from traditional silicon-based processors**. Here are some potential ways brain organoids could be used:\n\n- **Neural Network Computing**: The neurons in brain organoids can create **networks** that transmit electrical signals in ways similar to how the human brain processes information. These networks could, in theory, be used for computations, memory storage, or decision-making tasks.\n  \n- **Learning and Adaptation**: Unlike traditional processors, brain organoids could have the potential for **learning and adaptability**. Neurons can form and strengthen connections based on experience (similar to how our brains learn), so brain organoid bio-processors could potentially improve over time in ways that current AI systems cannot.\n\n- **Energy Efficiency**: Biological systems, like the human brain, are extremely **energy-efficient** compared to today\u2019s computers. If scientists can harness brain organoids for processing, it could lead to more efficient computing systems that require far less energy than current technologies.\n\n### 3. **Are These Bio-Processors Conscious or Self-Aware?**\nThis is a key point: **brain organoids are not conscious**. While they mimic some functions of a brain on a very small scale, they don\u2019t have the complexity or structure needed for sentience or self-awareness.\n\n- **No Consciousness**: Although they may be able to carry out computations or process information in a bio-inspired way, these organoids are **not capable of subjective experience**, thought, or awareness. They are more like very basic biological machines than living, thinking beings.\n\n- **Ethical Considerations**: However, there are ethical concerns as this research progresses. If bio-processors were to become more complex, at what point do we need to start thinking about their rights or autonomy? For now, this is far off, but it\u2019s a debate that scientists are starting to consider as the field of organoid intelligence advances.\n\n### 4. **How Close Are We to Using Brain Organoids as Processors?**\nThis technology is still in its early stages, but significant progress is being made:\n\n- **Proof of Concept**: Scientists have already shown that brain organoids can form **neural networks** and respond to stimuli. For example, organoids have been shown to exhibit activity that resembles learning on a small scale. This is a far cry from building a full-fledged &quot;bio-computer,&quot; but it shows that biological processing is possible.\n\n- **Challenges**: There are major challenges in scaling this up to the level where brain organoids could be used for advanced computing. For one, current brain organoids are very small and simple compared to the human brain. Also, interfacing biological systems with traditional computers is extremely complex\u2014scientists would need to figure out how to &quot;read&quot; and &quot;write&quot; information into the brain organoid bio-processors in a practical way.\n\n### 5. **Potential Benefits of Brain Organoid Processors**\n- **New AI Paradigms**: If we can successfully integrate brain organoid processors, it could create a new kind of AI\u2014one that mimics the adaptability, learning, and problem-solving abilities of biological brains, but on a much smaller scale.\n  \n- **Biocompatible Computing**: Brain organoids might also lead to more **biocompatible computing**, which could be especially useful in medical applications like brain-computer interfaces or neural prosthetics. For example, bio-processors could work alongside traditional AI systems to help people with neurological conditions.\n\n- **Ethical, Faster Learning Systems**: Bio-processors might offer **faster, more adaptable learning** in AI systems compared to silicon-based models like me. Since biological neurons are good at forming and strengthening connections based on experience, bio-processors could theoretically learn and evolve much faster in certain tasks.\n\n### 6. **Could an AI on Bio-Processors Be an &quot;Entity&quot;?**\n- **Still Lacking Consciousness**: Even if AI ran on brain organoid bio-processors, it would still function as a tool unless it demonstrated sentience or self-awareness. At the current stage of research, bio-processors are not conscious, and there\u2019s no evidence that increasing the complexity of a bio-processor would lead to consciousness.\n\n- **Potential Future**: If bio-processors become complex enough to simulate more sophisticated brain functions, some speculate that they could reach a point where we might consider them as more than just tools. However, this is purely speculative, and we\u2019re not close to this yet.\n\n### Summary:\nBrain organoid bio-processors are a real, emerging technology where lab-grown clusters of brain cells are used to mimic certain brain functions. While they hold potential for **biological computing** and **adaptable, learning-based systems**, they do not possess consciousness or self-awareness. If AI were to run on bio-processors, it would still likely function as a **highly advanced tool**, not as a conscious entity\u2014at least with our current understanding.\n\nDoes this help clarify things? Would you like to explore more about the potential applications or implications of this technology?"]}, "status": "finished_successfully", "end_turn": true, "weight": 1.0, "metadata": {"citations": [], "content_references": [], "gizmo_id": null, "message_type": null, "model_slug": "gpt-4o", "default_model_slug": "gpt-4o", "pad": "AAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAA", "parent_id": "5202eecc-22d6-4c9f-ba9e-02db2b1c94cb", "finish_details": {"type": "stop", "stop_tokens": [200002]}, "is_complete": true, "request_id": "8c8efa4e3f740e2b-MXP", "timestamp_": "absolute"}, "recipient": "all", "channel": null}, "parent": "5202eecc-22d6-4c9f-ba9e-02db2b1c94cb", "children": ["dcd51d1b-83e2-408c-bee6-d9ef13b76dec"]}, "dcd51d1b-83e2-408c-bee6-d9ef13b76dec": {"id": "dcd51d1b-83e2-408c-bee6-d9ef13b76dec", "message": {"id": "dcd51d1b-83e2-408c-bee6-d9ef13b76dec", "author": {"role": "user", "name": null, "metadata": {}}, "create_time": 1727308951.201627, "update_time": null, "content": {"content_type": "text", "parts": ["I heard they dropped them into a simulated environment. September 2023  August 2023  July 2023  June 2023  May 2023  April 2023  March ", "pub_date": null, "extra": null}], "original_query": null}, "command": "mclick", "args": ["[4, 13, 5, 8]"], "status": "finished", "is_complete": true, "message_type": null, "model_slug": "gpt-4o", "default_model_slug": "gpt-4o", "parent_id": "ebbaac9c-4548-4da3-b38f-7e298571d4f2", "request_id": "8c8efc4fcb400e2b-MXP", "timestamp_": "absolute"}, "recipient": "all", "channel": null}, "parent": "ebbaac9c-4548-4da3-b38f-7e298571d4f2", "children": ["09725a2a-c01f-4d15-8f8c-a92ab49e3632"]}, "09725a2a-c01f-4d15-8f8c-a92ab49e3632": {"id": "09725a2a-c01f-4d15-8f8c-a92ab49e3632", "message": {"id": "09725a2a-c01f-4d15-8f8c-a92ab49e3632", "author": {"role": "tool", "name": "browser", "metadata": {}}, "create_time": 1727308967.11491, "update_time": null, "content": {"content_type": "tether_quote", "url": "https://newatlas.com/robotics/brain-organoid-robot/", "domain": "newatlas.com", "text": "\nMore importantly, they can learn. The first time we encountered the concept was in the \u301040\u2020DishBrain project\u3011 at Monash University, Australia. In what must&#x27;ve felt like a Dr. Frankenstein moment, researchers grew about 800,000 brain cells onto a chip, put it into a simulated environment, and watched this horrific cyborg abomination learn to play Pong within about five minutes. The project was quickly \u301041\u2020funded by the Australian military\u3011, and spun out into a company called Cortical Labs. \n\n[Image 9: Cortical Labs has prototyped computing modules built around human brain cells, and is looking to commercialize this hybrid learning intelligence] \n\nCortical Labs has prototyped computing modules built around human brain cells, and is looking to commercialize this hybrid learning intelligence \n\nCortical Labs\n\nWhen \u301042\u2020we interviewed Cortical Labs&#x27; Chief Scientific Officer Brett Kagan\u3011, he told us that even at an early stage, human neuron-enhanced biocomputers appear to learn much faster, using much less power, than today&#x27;s AI machine learning chips, while demonstrating &quot;more intuition, insight and creativity.&quot; Our brains, after all, consume just a tiny 20 watts to run nature&#x27;s most powerful necktop computers. \n\n&quot;We&#x27;ve done tests against reinforcement learning,&quot; Kagan told us, &quot;and we find that in terms of how quickly the number of samples the system has to see before it starts to show meaningful learning, it&#x27;s chalk and cheese. The biological systems, even as basic and janky as they are right now, are still outperforming the best deep learning algorithms that people have generated. That&#x27;s pretty wild.&quot;\n\nOne downside \u2013 apart from some clearly thorny ethics \u2013 is that the &quot;wetware&quot; components need to be kept alive. That means keeping them fed, watered, temperature-controlled and protected from germs and viruses. Cortical&#x27;s record back in 2023 was about 12 months. \n\n[Image 10: Four human brain organoids, each with around 10,000 living human brain cells, wired into a biocomputing array in FinalSpark&#x27; s Neuroplatform] \n\nFour human brain organoids, each with around 10,000 living human brain cells, wired into a biocomputing array in FinalSpark&#x27; s Neuroplatform \n\nFinalSpark\n\nWe&#x27;ve since covered similar projects at Indiana University \u2013 where researchers let the brain cells self-organize into a \u301043\u2020three-dimensional ball-shaped &quot;Brainoware&quot; organoid\u3011 before poking electrodes into them \u2013 and Swiss startup FinalSpark, which has \u301044\u2020started using dopamine as a reward mechanism for its Neuroplatform\u3011 biocomputing chips. \n\nIf this is the first time you&#x27;ve heard about this brain-on-a-chip stuff, do pick your jaw up off the floor and read a few of those links \u2013 this is absolutely staggering work. And now Chinese researchers say they&#x27;re taking it to the next level. \n\nThe MetaBOC (BOC for brain-on-chip, of course) project brings together researchers from Tianjin University&#x27;s Haihe Laboratory of Brain-Computer Interaction and Human-Computer Integration with other teams from the Southern University of Science and Technology.\n\n[Image 11: Key components of brain-on-chip technologies, helpfully labelled in Chinese] \n\nKey components of brain-on-chip technologies, helpfully labelled in Chinese \n\nTianjin University\n\nIt&#x27;s an open-source piece of software designed to act as an interface between brain-on-a-chip biocomputers and other electronic devices, giving the brain organoid the ability to perceive the world through electronic signals, operate on it through whatever controls it&#x27;s given access to, and learn to master certain tasks. \n\nThe Tianjin team says it&#x27;s using ball-shaped organoids, much like the Brainoware team at Indiana, since their three-dimensional physical structure allows them to form more complex neural connections, much like they do in our brains. These organoids are \u301045\u2020grown under low-intensity focused ultrasound stimulation\u2020academic.oup.com\u3011, which the researchers say seems to give them a better intelligent foundation to build on.\n\nThe MetaBOC system also tries to meet intelligence with intelligence, using AI algorithms within the software to communicate with the brain cells&#x27; biological intelligence. \n\nThe Tianjin team specifically mentions robotics as an integration target, and provides the rather silly images above, as if deliberately trying to undermine the credibility of the work. A brain-on-a-chip biocomputer, says the team, can now learn to drive a robot, figuring out the controls and attempting tasks like avoiding obstacles, tracking targets, or learning to use arms and hands to grasp various objects. \n\nBecause the brain organoid is only able to &#x27;see&#x27; the world through the electrical signals provided to it, it can theoretically train itself up on how to pilot its mini-gundam in a fully simulated environment, allowing it to get most of its falling and crashing out of the way without jeopardizing its fleshy intelligence engine. \n\n[Image 12: No, the organoids probably won&#x27;t be that big to begin with. They will, however, require all sorts of support gear, including fluid and nutrient lines, anti-pathogenic seals, temperature-control and shock-proofing systems] \n\nNo, the organoids probably won&#x27;t be that big to begin with. They will, however, require all sorts of support gear, including fluid and nutrient lines, anti-pathogenic seals, temperature-control and shock-proofing systems \n\nTianjin University\n\nNow, to be crystal clear, the fully exposed, pink lollipop-style brain organoids in the robot images above are mockups \u2013 &quot;demonstration diagrams of future application scenarios&quot; \u2013 rather than brain-controlled prototypes. Perhaps the image below, from Cortical Labs, is a better representation of what these kinds of brains on chips will look like in the real world.\n\n[Image 13: Cortical Labs&#x27; &quot;wetware,&quot; looking particularly wet after a test session] \n\nCortical Labs&#x27; &quot;wetware,&quot; looking particularly wet after a test session \n\nCortical Labs\n\nBut either way, if you built a small robot with appropriate sensing and motor capabilities, we see no reason why human brain cells couldn&#x27;t soon be in there trying to get the hang of driving it. \n\nThis is a phenomenal time for science and technology, with projects like \u301046\u2020Neuralink\u3011 aiming to hook high-bandwidth computer interfaces straight into your brain, while projects like MetaBOC grow human brain cells into computers, and the surging AI industry attempts to overtake the best of biological intelligence with some strange facsimile built entirely in silicon.\n\nScience and tech are forced to get philosophical as they slam up against the limits of our understanding; are dish-brains conscious? Are AIs conscious? Both may conceivably end up being indistinguishable from sentient beings at some point in the near future. What are the ethics once that happens? Are they different for biological and silicon-based intelligences?\n\n&quot;Let&#x27;s say,&quot; \u301042\u2020says Kagan in our extensive interview\u3011, &quot;that these systems do develop consciousness \u2013 in my opinion, very unlikely, but let&#x27;s say it does happen. Then you need to decide, well, is it actually ethically right to test with them or not? Because we do test on conscious creatures. You know, we test on animals, which I think have a lev", "title": "&#x27;Brain-in-a-jar&#x27; biocomputers can now learn to control robots", "tether_id": null}, "status": "finished_successfully", "end_turn": null, "weight": 0.0, "metadata": {"_cite_metadata": {"citation_format": {"name": "tether_og"}, "metadata_list": [{"type": "webpage", "title": "&#x27;Brain-in-a-jar&#x27; biocomputers can now learn to control robots", "url": "https://newatlas.com/robotics/brain-organoid-robot/", "text": "\nMore importantly, they can learn. "a19a60d1-b4fc-49fd-a3c0-2465faf780dc", "author": {"role": "assistant", "name": null, "metadata": {}}, "create_time": 1727308967.115092, "update_time": null, "content": {"content_type": "text", "parts": ["Yes, researchers have indeed been experimenting with **brain organoids** in **simulated environments** to explore their potential for learning and interacting with the world. A notable example of this is the **DishBrain project** at Monash University in Australia. Scientists grew about **800,000 human brain cells** onto a chip and placed the organoids in a simulated environment where they were able to learn simple tasks, such as playing the game **Pong**. Incredibly, the brain organoid learned to play within just **five minutes**, demonstrating a remarkable ability to adapt and learn in a digital environment. This kind of experimentation pushes the boundaries of **biological computing**.\n\nAdditionally, there have been further advancements in projects like **MetaBOC**, which integrates brain organoids into robots. These brain organoids &quot;perceive&quot; the environment through electrical signals and then learn to operate controls within the simulated world, allowing them to perform tasks like avoiding obstacles or controlling robotic arms. Although these experiments are still in their early stages, they are showing that **bio-computing systems** can exhibit learning capabilities that surpass traditional AI in certain contexts\u301092\u2020source\u3011\u301093\u2020source\u3011.\n\nThese bio-processors require special care, like providing nutrients and maintaining temperature control, to keep the living brain cells alive. While it&#x27;s still far from building fully functional brain-powered robots, the research is opening up fascinating possibilities for the future of **biocomputing**\u301094\u2020source\u3011.\n\nIt&#x27;s an exciting time for science as we explore the intersection of biology and technology! Let me know if you&#x27;d like to explore this topic further."]}, "status": "finished_successfully", "end_turn": true, "weight": 1.0, "metadata": {"citations": [{"start_ix": 1237, "end_ix": 1248, "citation_format_type": "tether_og", "metadata": {"type": "webpage", "title": "MetaBOC: The Future of Brain-Computer Interaction and Biocomputing \u2013 Impact Lab", "url": "https://www.impactlab.com/2024/07/04/metaboc-the-future-of-brain-computer-interaction-and-biocomputing/", "text": "\nIt\u2019s important to note that the exposed brain organoids in the robot images are mockups intended to illustrate future applications, rather than actual brain-controlled prototypes. A more realistic representation of these biocomputers is provided by images from Cortical Labs, showing what these brain-on-chip systems might look like in practical use.\n\nBy Impact Lab\n\n## Post Archives\n\nArchives  Select Month September 2024  August 2024  July 2024  June 2024  May 2024  April 2024  March 2024  February 2024  January 2024  December 2023  November 2023  October 2023  September 2023  August 2023  July 2023  June 2023  May 2023  April 2023  March ", "pub_date": null, "extra": {"cited_message_idx": 92, "search_result_idx": null, "evidence_text": "source", "cloud_doc_url": null}}}, {"start_ix": 1248, "end_ix": 1259, "citation_format_type": "tether_og", "metadata": {"type": "webpage", "title": "&#x27;Brain-in-a-jar&#x27; biocomputers can now learn to control robots", "url": "https://newatlas.com/robotics/brain-organoid-robot/", "text": "\nMore importantly, they can learn. The first time we encountered the concept was in the \u301040\u2020DishBrain project\u3011 at Monash University, Australia. In what must&#x27;ve felt like a Dr. Frankenstein moment, researchers grew about 800,000 brain cells onto a chip, put it into a simulated environment, and watched this horrific cyborg abomination learn to play Pong within about five minutes. The project was quickly \u301041\u2020funded by the Australian military\u3011, and spun out into a company called Cortical Labs. \n\n[Image 9: Cortical Labs has prototyped computing modules built around human brain cells, and is looking to commercialize this hybrid learning intelligence] \n\nCortical Labs has prototyped computing modules built around human brain cells, and is looking to commercialize this hybrid learning intelligence \n\nCortical Labs\n\nWhen \u301042\u2020we interviewed Cortical Labs&#x27; Chief Scientific Officer Brett Kagan\u3011, he told us that even at an early stage, human neuron-enhanced biocomputers appear to learn much faster, using much less power, than today&#x27;s AI machine learning chips, while demonstrating &quot;more intuition, insight and creativity.&quot; Our brains, after all, consume just a tiny 20 watts to run nature&#x27;s most powerful necktop computers. \n\n&quot;We&#x27;ve done tests against reinforcement learning,&quot; Kagan told us, &quot;and we find that in terms of how quickly the number of samples the system has to see before it starts to show meaningful learning, it&#x27;s chalk and cheese. The biological systems, even as basic and janky as they are right now, are still outperforming the best deep learning algorithms that people have generated. That&#x27;s pretty wild.&quot;\n\nOne downside \u2013 apart from some clearly thorny ethics \u2013 is that the &quot;wetware&quot; components need to be kept alive. That means keeping them fed, watered, temperature-controlled and protected from germs and viruses. Cortical&#x27;s record back in 2023 was about 12 months. \n\n[Image 10: Four human brain organoids, each with around 10,000 living human brain cells, wired into a biocomputing array in FinalSpark&#x27; s Neuroplatform] \n\nFour human brain organoids, each with around 10,000 living human brain cells, wired into a biocomputing array in FinalSpark&#x27; s Neuroplatform \n\nFinalSpark\n\nWe&#x27;ve since covered similar projects at Indiana University \u2013 where researchers let the brain cells self-organize into a \u301043\u2020three-dimensional ball-shaped &quot;Brainoware&quot; organoid\u3011 before poking electrodes into them \u2013 and Swiss startup FinalSpark, which has \u301044\u2020started using dopamine as a reward mechanism for its Neuroplatform\u3011 biocomputing chips. \n\nIf this is the first time you&#x27;ve heard about this brain-on-a-chip stuff, do pick your jaw up off the floor and read a few of those links \u2013 this is absolutely staggering work. And now Chinese researchers say they&#x27;re taking it to the next level. \n\nThe MetaBOC (BOC for brain-on-chip, of course) project brings together researchers from Tianjin University&#x27;s Haihe Laboratory of Brain-Computer Interaction and Human-Computer Integration with other teams from the Southern University of Science and Technology.\n\n[Image 11: Key components of brain-on-chip technologies, helpfully labelled in Chinese] \n\nKey components of brain-on-chip technologies, helpfully labelled in Chinese \n\nTianjin University\n\nIt&#x27;s an open-source piece of software designed to act as an interface between brain-on-a-chip biocomputers and other electronic devices, giving the brain organoid the ability to perceive the world through electronic signals, operate on it through whatever controls it&#x27;s given access to, and learn to master certain tasks. \n\nThe Tianjin team says it&#x27;s using ball-shaped organoids, much like the Brainoware team at Indiana, since their three-dimensional physical structure allows them to form more complex neural connections, much like they do in our brains. These organoids are \u301045\u2020grown under low-intensity focused ultrasound stimulation\u2020academic.oup.com\u3011, which the researchers say seems to give them a better intelligent foundation to build on.\n\nThe MetaBOC system also tries to meet intelligence with intelligence, using AI algorithms within the software to communicate with the brain cells&#x27; biological intelligence. \n\nThe Tianjin team specifically mentions robotics as an integration target, and provides the rather silly images above, as if deliberately trying to undermine the credibility of the work. A brain-on-a-chip biocomputer, says the team, can now learn to drive a robot, figuring out the controls and attempting tasks like avoiding obstacles, tracking targets, or learning to use arms and hands to grasp various objects. \n\nBecause the brain organoid is only able to &#x27;see&#x27; the world through the electrical signals provided to it, it can theoretically train itself up on how to pilot its mini-gundam in a fully simulated environment, allowing it to get most of its falling and crashing out of the way without jeopardizing its fleshy intelligence engine. \n\n[Image 12: No, the organoids probably won&#x27;t be that big to begin with. They will, however, require all sorts of support gear, including fluid and nutrient lines, anti-pathogenic seals, temperature-control and shock-proofing systems] \n\nNo, the organoids probably won&#x27;t be that big to begin with. They will, however, require all sorts of support gear, including fluid and nutrient lines, anti-pathogenic seals, temperature-control and shock-proofing systems \n\nTianjin University\n\nNow, to be crystal clear, the fully exposed, pink lollipop-style brain organoids in the robot images above are mockups \u2013 &quot;demonstration diagrams of future application scenarios&quot; \u2013 rather than brain-controlled prototypes. Perhaps the image below, from Cortical Labs, is a better representation of what these kinds of brains on chips will look like in the real world.\n\n[Image 13: Cortical Labs&#x27; &quot;wetware,&quot; looking particularly wet after a test session] \n\nCortical Labs&#x27; &quot;wetware,&quot; looking particularly wet after a test session \n\nCortical Labs\n\nBut either way, if you built a small robot with appropriate sensing and motor capabilities, we see no reason why human brain cells couldn&#x27;t soon be in there trying to get the hang of driving it. \n\nThis is a phenomenal time for science and technology, with projects like \u301046\u2020Neuralink\u3011 aiming to hook high-bandwidth computer interfaces straight into your brain, while projects like MetaBOC grow human brain cells into computers, and the surging AI industry attempts to overtake the best of biological intelligence with some strange facsimile built entirely in silicon.\n\nScience and tech are forced to get philosophical as they slam up against the limits of our understanding; are dish-brains conscious? Are AIs conscious? Both may conceivably end up being indistinguishable from sentient beings at some point in the near future. What are the ethics once that happens? Are they different for biological and silicon-based intelligences?\n\n&quot;Let&#x27;s say,&quot; \u301042\u2020says Kagan in our extensive interview\u3011, &quot;that these systems do develop consciousness \u2013 in my opinion, very unlikely, but let&#x27;s say it does happen. Then you need to decide, well, is it actually ethically right to test with them or not? Because we do test on conscious creatures. You know, we test on animals, which I think have a lev", "pub_date": null, "extra": {"cited_message_idx": 93, "search_result_idx": null, "evidence_text": "source", "cloud_doc_url": null}}}, {"start_ix": 1566, "end_ix": 1577, "citation_format_type": "tether_og", "metadata": {"type": "webpage", "title": "\u2018Biocomputer\u2019 combines lab-grown brain tissue with electronic hardware", "url": "https://www.nature.com/articles/d41586-023-03975-7", "text": "\nNature 624, 481 (2023)\n\ndoi: https://doi.org/10.1038/d41586-023-03975-7\n\n## References\n\n  1. Archives\n\nArchives  Select Month September 2024  August 2024  July 2024  June 2024  May 2024  April 2024  March 2024  February 2024  January 2024  December 2023  November 2023  October 2023  September 2023  August 2023  July 2023  June 2023  May 2023  April 2023  March "}, {"matched_text": "\u301093\u2020source\u3011", "start_idx": 1248, "end_idx": 1259, "alt": null, "type": "webpage_extended", "title": "&#x27;Brain-in-a-jar&#x27; biocomputers can now learn to control robots", "url": "https://newatlas.com/robotics/brain-organoid-robot/", "pub_date": null, "snippet": "\nMore importantly, they can learn. The first time we encountered the concept was in the \u301040\u2020DishBrain project\u3011 at Monash University, Australia. In what must&#x27;ve felt like a Dr. Frankenstein moment, researchers grew about 800,000 brain cells onto a chip, put it into a simulated environment, and watched this horrific cyborg abomination learn to play Pong within about five minutes. The project was quickly \u301041\u2020funded by the Australian military\u3011, and spun out into a company called Cortical Labs. \n\n[Image 9: Cortical Labs has prototyped computing modules built around human brain cells, and is looking to commercialize this hybrid learning intelligence] \n\nCortical Labs has prototyped computing modules built around human brain cells, and is looking to commercialize this hybrid learning intelligence \n\nCortical Labs\n\nWhen \u301042\u2020we interviewed Cortical Labs&#x27; Chief Scientific Officer Brett Kagan\u3011, he told us that even at an early stage, human neuron-enhanced biocomputers appear to learn much faster, using much less power, than today&#x27;s AI machine learning chips, while demonstrating &quot;more intuition, insight and creativity.&quot; Our brains, after all, consume just a tiny 20 watts to run nature&#x27;s most powerful necktop computers. \n\n&quot;We&#x27;ve done tests against reinforcement learning,&quot; Kagan told us, &quot;and we find that in terms of how quickly the number of samples the system has to see before it starts to show meaningful learning, it&#x27;s chalk and cheese. The biological systems, even as basic and janky as they are right now, are still outperforming the best deep learning algorithms that people have generated. That&#x27;s pretty wild.&quot;\n\nOne downside \u2013 apart from some clearly thorny ethics \u2013 is that the &quot;wetware&quot; components need to be kept alive. That means keeping them fed, watered, temperature-controlled and protected from germs and viruses. Cortical&#x27;s record back in 2023 was about 12 months. \n\n[Image 10: Four human brain organoids, each with around 10,000 living human brain cells, wired into a biocomputing array in FinalSpark&#x27; s Neuroplatform] \n\nFour human brain organoids, each with around 10,000 living human brain cells, wired into a biocomputing array in FinalSpark&#x27; s Neuroplatform \n\nFinalSpark\n\nWe&#x27;ve since covered similar projects at Indiana University \u2013 where researchers let the brain cells self-organize into a \u301043\u2020three-dimensional ball-shaped &quot;Brainoware&quot; organoid\u3011 before poking electrodes into them \u2013 and Swiss startup FinalSpark, which has \u301044\u2020started using dopamine as a reward mechanism for its Neuroplatform\u3011 biocomputing chips. \n\nIf this is the first time you&#x27;ve heard about this brain-on-a-chip stuff, do pick your jaw up off the floor and read a few of those links \u2013 this is absolutely staggering work. And now Chinese researchers say they&#x27;re taking it to the next level. \n\nThe MetaBOC (BOC for brain-on-chip, of course) project brings together researchers from Tianjin University&#x27;s Haihe Laboratory of Brain-Computer Interaction and Human-Computer Integration with other teams from the Southern University of Science and Technology.\n\n[Image 11: Key components of brain-on-chip technologies, helpfully labelled in Chinese] \n\nKey components of brain-on-chip technologies, helpfully labelled in Chinese \n\nTianjin University\n\nIt&#x27;s an open-source piece of software designed to act as an interface between brain-on-a-chip biocomputers and other electronic devices, giving the brain organoid the ability to perceive the world through electronic signals, operate on it through whatever controls it&#x27;s given access to, and learn to master certain tasks. \n\nThe Tianjin team says it&#x27;s using ball-shaped organoids, much like the Brainoware team at Indiana, since their three-dimensional physical structure allows them to form more complex neural connections, much like they do in our brains. These organoids are \u301045\u2020grown under low-intensity focused ultrasound stimulation\u2020academic.oup.com\u3011, which the researchers say seems to give them a better intelligent foundation to build on.\n\nThe MetaBOC system also tries to meet intelligence with intelligence, using AI algorithms within the software to communicate with the brain cells&#x27; biological intelligence. \n\nThe Tianjin team specifically mentions robotics as an integration target, and provides the rather silly images above, as if deliberately trying to undermine the credibility of the work. A brain-on-a-chip biocomputer, says the team, can now learn to drive a robot, figuring out the controls and attempting tasks like avoiding obstacles, tracking targets, or learning to use arms and hands to grasp various objects. \n\nBecause the brain organoid is only able to &#x27;see&#x27; the world through the electrical signals provided to it, it can theoretically train itself up on how to pilot its mini-gundam in a fully simulated environment, allowing it to get most of its falling and crashing out of the way without jeopardizing its fleshy intelligence engine. \n\n[Image 12: No, the organoids probably won&#x27;t be that big to begin with. They will, however, require all sorts of support gear, including fluid and nutrient lines, anti-pathogenic seals, temperature-control and shock-proofing systems] \n\nNo, the organoids probably won&#x27;t be that big to begin with. They will, however, require all sorts of support gear, including fluid and nutrient lines, anti-pathogenic seals, temperature-control and shock-proofing systems \n\nTianjin University\n\nNow, to be crystal clear, the fully exposed, pink lollipop-style brain organoids in the robot images above are mockups \u2013 &quot;demonstration diagrams of future application scenarios&quot; \u2013 rather than brain-controlled prototypes. Perhaps the image below, from Cortical Labs, is a better representation of what these kinds of brains on chips will look like in the real world.\n\n[Image 13: Cortical Labs&#x27; &quot;wetware,&quot; looking particularly wet after a test session] \n\nCortical Labs&#x27; &quot;wetware,&quot; looking particularly wet after a test session \n\nCortical Labs\n\nBut either way, if you built a small robot with appropriate sensing and motor capabilities, we see no reason why human brain cells couldn&#x27;t soon be in there trying to get the hang of driving it. \n\nThis is a phenomenal time for science and technology, with projects like \u301046\u2020Neuralink\u3011 aiming to hook high-bandwidth computer interfaces straight into your brain, while projects like MetaBOC grow human brain cells into computers, and the surging AI industry attempts to overtake the best of biological intelligence with some strange facsimile built entirely in silicon.\n\nScience and tech are forced to get philosophical as they slam up against the limits of our understanding; are dish-brains conscious? Are AIs conscious? Both may conceivably end up being indistinguishable from sentient beings at some point in the near future. What are the ethics once that happens? Are they different for biological and silicon-based intelligences?\n\n&quot;Let&#x27;s say,&quot; \u301042\u2020says Kagan in our extensive interview\u3011, &quot;that these systems do develop consciousness \u2013 in my opinion, very unlikely, but let&#x27;s say it does happen. Then you need to decide, well, is it actually ethically right to test with them or not? Because we do test on conscious creatures. You know, we test on animals, which I think have a lev"}, {"matched_text": "\u301094\u2020source\u3011", "start_idx": 1566, "end_idx": 1577, "alt": null, "type": "webpage_extended", "title": "\u2018Biocomputer\u2019 combines lab-grown brain tissue with electronic hardware", "url": "https://www.nature.com/articles/d41586-023-03975-7", "pub_date": null, "snippet": "\nNature 624, 481 (2023)\n\ndoi: https://doi.org/10.1038/d41586-023-03975-7\n\n## References\n\n  1. It is often used as a natural preservative in dog foods and can have antioxidant properties.\n- **Benefits**: Rosemary may help improve digestion and has antimicrobial properties that could benefit your dog\u2019s overall health.\n- **Caution**: Some dogs may have sensitivities, and large amounts could potentially cause digestive upset. Always start with small quantities.\n\n### Potatoes:\n- **Cooked potatoes are generally safe**: Dogs can eat cooked, plain potatoes in moderation. Potatoes provide vitamins and fiber, but they should not be seasoned with butter, salt, or harmful spices (like garlic or onion).\n- **Avoid raw potatoes**: Raw potatoes, especially those with green spots or sprouted areas, contain **solanine**, a toxin that can be harmful to dogs.\n- **Mashed potatoes**: These are fine as long as they don\u2019t contain added ingredients like butter, milk, garlic, or onion.\n\nAs always, it\u2019s best to consult with your vet before introducing new foods into your dog\u2019s diet to ensure they\u2019re safe and healthy for your pet."]}, "status": \n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Leading With Diplomacy And American Values \u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a090  \n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Strongest Military In The World \u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a092\n\n## Chapter One: Growing Our Economy from the Bottom Up &amp; Middle Out\n\nThis election is a choice between two very different economic visions for America: Donald Trump, who sees the world from his country club at Mar-a-Lago; and Joe Biden, who sees it from kitchen tables in Scranton like the one he grew up around. His economic agenda is about Main Street, not Wall Street. It&#x27;s about ending the days of trickle-down economics and investing in America \u2013 in all Americans \u2013 and delivering for communities too long left behind.\n\nWhile Democrats keep fighting to lower costs for working families, Trump is rigging our economy for his Mar-a-Lago friends and billionaire donors, who like him, are only in it for themselves.\n\nAs president, Trump doubled down on the trickle-down policies of the past, cutting investment in infrastructure and education, and rewarding big corporations that ship jobs and profits overseas. He vowed to bring new factories to communities across America, but left nothing behind but a string of broken promises.\n\nDemocrats have a different record. We&#x27;re delivering on President Biden&#x27;s pledge to rebuild our economy from the middle out and bottom up, not the top down. We&#x27;re investing in America \u2013 in our infrastructure, our industry, our people, and our future. While Trump left office with historic budget deficits and the worst jobs record since Herbert Hoover, since President Biden took office, this country has come back from the brink, the deficit has fallen by over $1 trillion, and we have the best jobs record since John F. Kennedy. We&#x27;re powering the strongest economic recovery in the world.\n\nECONOMIC PROGRESS\n\nAt the start of the Biden-Harris Administration, in the midst of the worst economic crisis in 100 years, experts feared a stagnating recovery and even worried about a new recession. But Democrats chose to put workers first, and instead of recession, America has seen remarkable strength and resilience. Our economy grew by 3.1 percent last year \u2013 the fastest rate of any major economy in the world.\n\nWe&#x27;ve added nearly 16 million jobs \u2013 not only recovering all the positions lost during Trump&#x27;s botched handling of COVID, but also adding 6.3 million more than existed before the pandemic \u2013 surpassing pre-pandemic projections for the labor market. During this Administration, 30 states from Mississippi to Pennsylvania have seen record-low unemployment; and the run of low unemployment nationwide hasn&#x27;t been this long in over 50 years. Wages are up across the board, and rising fastest for lower-income workers, Black workers, Latinos, and women. Today&#x27;s recovery is the fairest on record; in just four years, we&#x27;ve erased 40 percent of the wage inequality gap that took four decades to build. A record 18 million small business applications have been filed since President Biden took office, each one of them an act of hope.\n\nWhile too many families still feel the pain of inflation at the grocery store, or around the kitchen table when they sit down to pay their bills, we&#x27;re making progress. Wages are rising faster than prices, and inflation today is down nearly two-thirds from its peak. We have to finish the job. Democrats will keep fighting to prevent the kind of supply chain shocks and corporate greed that have done so much to raise prices. And we&#x27;ll keep investing in American workers, American jobs, and American families, bringing factories home to win the race for the future. Democrats know the story of the middle class isn&#x27;t separate from the state of the economy \u2013 it&#x27;s at its heart. And we&#x27;ll never quit fighting to make sure that everyone is in on the deal.\n\nINVESTING IN AMERICA\n\nInfrastructure\n\nWe can&#x27;t have the best economy in the world if we don&#x27;t have the best infrastructure. And for generations, American infrastructure was the envy of the world. But over the years, we stopped investing in it, and we fell to thirteenth in infrastructure rankings. The Trump Administration declared it &quot;Infrastructure Week&quot; every week for four years, and never built a thing. But under President Biden, we&#x27;re finally rebuilding our roads, bridges, ports, airports, water systems, electric grids, broadband, and more, paving the way for a great American &quot;Infrastructure Decade&quot; that will create hundreds of thousands of good-paying union jobs.\n\nThe Bipartisan Infrastructure Law is breaking ground on over 57,000 projects across 4,500 communities nationwide.  \n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Meeting Our Nation&#x27;s Sacred Obligation To  \n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 \u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Veterans And Military Families Nine: Strengthening American Leadership Worldwide 79\n\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Europe  \n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Indo-Pacific  \n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0China 82  \n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The Middle East &amp; North Africa  \n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Western 87  \n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Africa\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 88  \n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Strengthening The U.S. And Global Economy \u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 89  \n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Leading With Diplomacy And American Values \u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a090  \n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Strongest Military In The World \u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a092\n\n## Chapter One: Growing Our Economy from the Bottom Up &amp; Middle Out\n\nThis election is a choice between two very different economic visions for America: Donald Trump, who sees the world from his country club at Mar-a-Lago; and Joe Biden, who sees it from kitchen tables in Scranton like the one he grew up around. His economic agenda is about Main Street, not Wall Street. It&#x27;s about ending the days of trickle-down economics and investing in America \u2013 in all Americans \u2013 and delivering for communities too long left behind.\n\nWhile Democrats keep fighting to lower costs for working families, Trump is rigging our economy for his Mar-a-Lago friends and billionaire donors, who like him, are only in it for themselves.\n\nAs president, Trump doubled down on the trickle-down policies of the past, cutting investment in infrastructure and education, and rewarding big corporations that ship jobs and profits overseas. He vowed to bring new factories to communities across America, but left nothing behind but a string of broken promises.\n\nDemocrats have a different record. We&#x27;re delivering on President Biden&#x27;s pledge to rebuild our economy from the middle out and bottom up, not the top down. We&#x27;re investing in America \u2013 in our infrastructure, our industry, our people, and our future. While Trump left office with historic budget deficits and the worst jobs record since Herbert Hoover, since President Biden took office, this country has come back from the brink, the deficit has fallen by over $1 trillion, and we have the best jobs record since John F. Kennedy. We&#x27;re powering the strongest economic recovery in the world.\n\nECONOMIC PROGRESS\n\nAt the start of the Biden-Harris Administration, in the midst of the worst economic crisis in 100 years, experts feared a stagnating recovery and even worried about a new recession. But Democrats chose to put workers first, and instead of recession, America has seen remarkable strength and resilience. Our economy grew by 3.1 percent last year \u2013 the fastest rate of any major economy in the world.\n\nWe&#x27;ve added nearly 16 million jobs \u2013 not only recovering all the positions lost during Trump&#x27;s botched handling of COVID, but also adding 6.3 million more than existed before the pandemic \u2013 surpassing pre-pandemic projections for the labor market. During this Administration, 30 states from Mississippi to Pennsylvania have seen record-low unemployment; and the run of low unemployment nationwide hasn&#x27;t been this long in over 50 years. Wages are up across the board, and rising fastest for lower-income workers, Black workers, Latinos, and women. Today&#x27;s recovery is the fairest on record; in just four years, we&#x27;ve erased 40 percent of the wage inequality gap that took four decades to build. A record 18 million small business applications have been filed since President Biden took office, each one of them an act of hope.\n\nWhile too many families still feel the pain of inflation at the grocery store, or around the kitchen table when they sit down to pay their bills, we&#x27;re making progress. Wages are rising faster than prices, and inflation today is down nearly two-thirds from its peak. We have to finish the job. Democrats will keep fighting to prevent the kind of supply chain shocks and corporate greed that have done so much to raise prices. And we&#x27;ll keep investing in American workers, American jobs, and American families, bringing factories home to win the race for the future. Democrats know the story of the middle class isn&#x27;t separate from the state of the economy \u2013 it&#x27;s at its heart. And we&#x27;ll never quit fighting to make sure that everyone is in on the deal.\n\nINVESTING IN AMERICA\n\nInfrastructure\n\nWe can&#x27;t have the best economy in the world if we don&#x27;t have the best infrastructure. And for generations, American infrastructure was the envy of the world. But over the years, we stopped investing in it, and we fell to thirteenth in infrastructure rankings. The Trump Administration declared it &quot;Infrastructure Week&quot; every week for four years, and never built a thing. But under President Biden, we&#x27;re finally rebuilding our roads, bridges, ports, airports, water systems, electric grids, broadband, and more, paving the way for a great American &quot;Infrastructure Decade&quot; that will create hundreds of thousands of good-paying union jobs.\n\nThe Bipartisan Infrastructure Law is breaking ground on over 57,000 projects across 4,500 communities nationwide. Let\u2019s break it down:\n\n### **1979 Democratic Platform**\nIn the late 1970s, during Jimmy Carter\u2019s presidency, the Democratic Party focused on several key issues:\n- **Inflation and the Economy**: The U.S. was dealing with high inflation and unemployment (the &quot;stagflation&quot; crisis), so economic recovery was a central theme. There was an emphasis on reducing inflation, creating jobs, and maintaining the social safety net, like Social Security and Medicare.\n- **Energy Crisis**: After the 1973 oil embargo and the 1979 energy crisis, the party strongly pushed for **energy independence** and renewable energy investments. There was a focus on reducing dependency on foreign oil and improving fuel efficiency standards.\n- **Human Rights and Foreign Policy**: The Democratic Party championed **human rights** as a cornerstone of U.S. foreign policy, promoting democracy abroad and reducing U.S. military interventions, which contrasted with the Cold War-era politics.\n  \n### **2024 Democratic Platform**\nThe 2024 platform reflects a much broader and more progressive scope, influenced by current challenges like climate change, economic inequality, and healthcare. Some key priorities include:\n- **Climate Action**: A strong focus on **combating climate change** through investment in clean energy, environmental protection, and infrastructure projects aimed at achieving net-zero emissions.\n- **Healthcare as a Right**: Universal access to affordable healthcare remains a major priority, with calls to expand programs like **Medicare** and reduce prescription drug costs.\n- **Social Justice and Equality**: The 2024 platform emphasizes **racial equity**, **LGBTQ+ rights**, and **women\u2019s rights**, including the protection of reproductive rights and advancing gender equality.\n- **Economic Growth for All**: There\u2019s a strong focus on **building the economy from the bottom up and middle out**, which includes raising wages, creating more union jobs, and expanding infrastructure investments to reduce income inequality\u3010119\u2020source\u3011\u3010120\u2020source\u3011.\n\nIn contrast to the more moderate and centrist focus of the late 1970s, today\u2019s platform embraces progressive ideals, reflecting the changing dynamics within the Democratic Party and the evolving concerns of modern voters."]}, "status": \n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Leading With Diplomacy And American Values \u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a090  \n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Strongest Military In The World \u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a092\n\n## Chapter One: Growing Our Economy from the Bottom Up &amp; Middle Out\n\nThis election is a choice between two very different economic visions for America: Donald Trump, who sees the world from his country club at Mar-a-Lago; and Joe Biden, who sees it from kitchen tables in Scranton like the one he grew up around. His economic agenda is about Main Street, not Wall Street. It&#x27;s about ending the days of trickle-down economics and investing in America \u2013 in all Americans \u2013 and delivering for communities too long left behind.\n\nWhile Democrats keep fighting to lower costs for working families, Trump is rigging our economy for his Mar-a-Lago friends and billionaire donors, who like him, are only in it for themselves.\n\nAs president, Trump doubled down on the trickle-down policies of the past, cutting investment in infrastructure and education, and rewarding big corporations that ship jobs and profits overseas. He vowed to bring new factories to communities across America, but left nothing behind but a string of broken promises.\n\nDemocrats have a different record. We&#x27;re delivering on President Biden&#x27;s pledge to rebuild our economy from the middle out and bottom up, not the top down. We&#x27;re investing in America \u2013 in our infrastructure, our industry, our people, and our future. While Trump left office with historic budget deficits and the worst jobs record since Herbert Hoover, since President Biden took office, this country has come back from the brink, the deficit has fallen by over $1 trillion, and we have the best jobs record since John F. Kennedy. We&#x27;re powering the strongest economic recovery in the world.\n\nECONOMIC PROGRESS\n\nAt the start of the Biden-Harris Administration, in the midst of the worst economic crisis in 100 years, experts feared a stagnating recovery and even worried about a new recession. But Democrats chose to put workers first, and instead of recession, America has seen remarkable strength and resilience. Our economy grew by 3.1 percent last year \u2013 the fastest rate of any major economy in the world.\n\nWe&#x27;ve added nearly 16 million jobs \u2013 not only recovering all the positions lost during Trump&#x27;s botched handling of COVID, but also adding 6.3 million more than existed before the pandemic \u2013 surpassing pre-pandemic projections for the labor market. During this Administration, 30 states from Mississippi to Pennsylvania have seen record-low unemployment; and the run of low unemployment nationwide hasn&#x27;t been this long in over 50 years. Wages are up across the board, and rising fastest for lower-income workers, Black workers, Latinos, and women. Today&#x27;s recovery is the fairest on record; in just four years, we&#x27;ve erased 40 percent of the wage inequality gap that took four decades to build. A record 18 million small business applications have been filed since President Biden took office, each one of them an act of hope.\n\nWhile too many families still feel the pain of inflation at the grocery store, or around the kitchen table when they sit down to pay their bills, we&#x27;re making progress. Wages are rising faster than prices, and inflation today is down nearly two-thirds from its peak. We have to finish the job. Democrats will keep fighting to prevent the kind of supply chain shocks and corporate greed that have done so much to raise prices. And we&#x27;ll keep investing in American workers, American jobs, and American families, bringing factories home to win the race for the future. Democrats know the story of the middle class isn&#x27;t separate from the state of the economy \u2013 it&#x27;s at its heart. And we&#x27;ll never quit fighting to make sure that everyone is in on the deal.\n\nINVESTING IN AMERICA\n\nInfrastructure\n\nWe can&#x27;t have the best economy in the world if we don&#x27;t have the best infrastructure. And for generations, American infrastructure was the envy of the world. But over the years, we stopped investing in it, and we fell to thirteenth in infrastructure rankings. The Trump Administration declared it &quot;Infrastructure Week&quot; every week for four years, and never built a thing. But under President Biden, we&#x27;re finally rebuilding our roads, bridges, ports, airports, water systems, electric grids, broadband, and more, paving the way for a great American &quot;Infrastructure Decade&quot; that will create hundreds of thousands of good-paying union jobs.\n\nThe Bipartisan Infrastructure Law is breaking ground on over 57,000 projects across 4,500 communities nationwide.  \n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Meeting Our Nation&#x27;s Sacred Obligation To  \n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 \u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Veterans And Military Families \u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a077\n\nChapter Nine: Strengthening American Leadership Worldwide 79\n\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Europe \u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a079  \n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Indo-Pacific \u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a081  \n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0China 82  \n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The Middle East &amp; North Africa \u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a084  \n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Western Hemisphere\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 87  \n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Africa\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 88  \n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Strengthening The U.S. And Global Economy \u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 89  \n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Leading With Diplomacy And American Values \u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a090  \n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Strongest Military In The World \u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a092\n\n## Chapter One: Growing Our Economy from the Bottom Up &amp; Middle Out\n\nThis election is a choice between two very different economic visions for America: Donald Trump, who sees the world from his country club at Mar-a-Lago; and Joe Biden, who sees it from kitchen tables in Scranton like the one he grew up around. His economic agenda is about Main Street, not Wall Street. It&#x27;s about ending the days of trickle-down economics and investing in America \u2013 in all Americans \u2013 and delivering for communities too long left behind.\n\nWhile Democrats keep fighting to lower costs for working families, Trump is rigging our economy for his Mar-a-Lago friends and billionaire donors, who like him, are only in it for themselves.\n\nAs president, Trump doubled down on the trickle-down policies of the past, cutting investment in infrastructure and education, and rewarding big corporations that ship jobs and profits overseas. He vowed to bring new factories to communities across America, but left nothing behind but a string of broken promises.\n\nDemocrats have a different record. We&#x27;re delivering on President Biden&#x27;s pledge to rebuild our economy from the middle out and bottom up, not the top down. We&#x27;re investing in America \u2013 in our infrastructure, our industry, our people, and our future. While Trump left office with historic budget deficits and the worst jobs record since Herbert Hoover, since President Biden took office, this country has come back from the brink, the deficit has fallen by over $1 trillion, and we have the best jobs record since John F. Kennedy. We&#x27;re powering the strongest economic recovery in the world.\n\nECONOMIC PROGRESS\n\nAt the start of the Biden-Harris Administration, in the midst of the worst economic crisis in 100 years, experts feared a stagnating recovery and even worried about a new recession. But Democrats chose to put workers first, and instead of recession, America has seen remarkable strength and resilience. Our economy grew by 3.1 percent last year \u2013 the fastest rate of any major economy in the world.\n\nWe&#x27;ve added nearly 16 million jobs \u2013 not only recovering all the positions lost during Trump&#x27;s botched handling of COVID, but also adding 6.3 million more than existed before the pandemic \u2013 surpassing pre-pandemic projections for the labor market. During this Administration, 30 states from Mississippi to Pennsylvania have seen record-low unemployment; and the run of low unemployment nationwide hasn&#x27;t been this long in over 50 years. Wages are up across the board, and rising fastest for lower-income workers, Black workers, Latinos, and women. Today&#x27;s recovery is the fairest on record; in just four years, we&#x27;ve erased 40 percent of the wage inequality gap that took four decades to build. A record 18 million small business applications have been filed since President Biden took office, each one of them an act of hope.\n\nWhile too many families still feel the pain of inflation at the grocery store, or around the kitchen table when they sit down to pay their bills, we&#x27;re making progress. Wages are rising faster than prices, and inflation today is down nearly two-thirds from its peak. We have to finish the job. Democrats will keep fighting to prevent the kind of supply chain shocks and corporate greed that have done so much to raise prices. And we&#x27;ll keep investing in American workers, American jobs, and American families, bringing factories home to win the race for the future. Democrats know the story of the middle class isn&#x27;t separate from the state of the economy \u2013 it&#x27;s at its heart. And we&#x27;ll never quit fighting to make sure that everyone is in on the deal.\n\nINVESTING IN AMERICA\n\nInfrastructure\n\nWe can&#x27;t have the best economy in the world if we don&#x27;t have the best infrastructure. And for generations, American infrastructure was the envy of the world. But over the years, we stopped investing in it, and we fell to thirteenth in infrastructure rankings. The Trump Administration declared it &quot;Infrastructure Week&quot; every week for four years, and never built a thing. But under President Biden, we&#x27;re finally rebuilding our roads, bridges, ports, airports, water systems, electric grids, broadband, and more, paving the way for a great American &quot;Infrastructure Decade&quot; that will create hundreds of thousands of good-paying union jobs.\n\nThe Bipartisan Infrastructure Law is breaking ground on over 57,000 projects across 4,500 communities nationwide. The issues themselves may be similar, but the context, causes, and proposed solutions have evolved. Let\u2019s break it down:\n\n### 1. **Inflation and Unemployment**:\n- In **1979**, the U.S. faced **stagflation**\u2014a rare combination of high inflation and unemployment, partly driven by the oil crisis and supply chain shocks. The Carter administration struggled with how to tackle inflation without worsening unemployment.\n  \n- Today, **inflation and unemployment** are still significant issues, especially post-pandemic. While the causes now include pandemic-related supply chain disruptions and global geopolitical events (like the war in Ukraine affecting energy prices), the solutions focus more on balancing monetary policy (interest rates) and government intervention, such as stimulus programs. In 2024, Democrats emphasize wage growth, job creation, and lowering costs for families while promoting progressive policies on infrastructure and energy\u3010119\u2020source\u3011\u3010120\u2020source\u3011.\n\n### 2. **Handling Crises Abroad**:\n- In **1979**, the focus was largely on **Cold War tensions**, specifically the relationship with the Soviet Union, and managing crises in places like Iran (the hostage crisis) and Afghanistan. The Democratic Party\u2019s foreign policy at that time leaned toward **diplomacy and human rights**.\n\n- Fast forward to **2024**, and the Democrats are still grappling with **foreign crises**, such as managing relations with China, Russia, and conflicts in the Middle East, but now there\u2019s a stronger emphasis on **climate diplomacy**, **trade**, and **humanitarian issues** in a more interconnected world. While the topics may feel similar, today&#x27;s foreign policy debates include newer dimensions like cyber threats and globalized economies\u3010119\u2020source\u3011.\n\n### Why It Feels the Same:\nAt a high level, the **core challenges** (inflation, unemployment, foreign crises) reflect enduring struggles that every generation faces, which is why they may seem like the &quot;same old issues.&quot; However, the way political leaders frame these problems and the specific policies proposed have evolved with new economic theories, technologies, and global relationships.\n\nFor example:\n- The **Green New Deal** and renewable energy investments today weren\u2019t in the conversation in 1979, when the focus was on **oil dependency**.\n- Similarly, the current debate about **healthcare as a right** and **racial justice** is far more prominent today than it was back then.\n\nSo, while the themes are consistent, the **specifics of the challenges and proposed solutions** reflect changing times. Do you feel like current politics offers real solutions, or do you think they\u2019re still grappling with the same underlying issues from decades ago?"]}, "status": "finished_successfully",  \n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Expanding Legal Immigration &amp; Deterring Illegal Immigration \u00a0\u00a070\n\nChapter Eight: Advancing the President&#x27;s Unity Agenda
