 \n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Indo-Pacific \u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a081  \n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0China \u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 82  \n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The Middle East &amp; North Africa \u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a084  \n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Western Hemisphere\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 87  \n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Africa\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 88  \n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Strengthening The U.S. And Global Economy \u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 89  \n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Leading With Diplomacy And American Values \u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a090  \n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Strongest Military In The World \u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a092\n\n## Chapter One: Growing Our Economy from the Bottom Up &amp; Middle Out\n\nThis election is a choice between two very different economic visions for America: Donald Trump, who sees the world from his country club at Mar-a-Lago; and Joe Biden, who sees it from kitchen tables in Scranton like the one he grew up around. His economic agenda is about Main Street, not Wall Street. It&#x27;s about ending the days of trickle-down economics and investing in America \u2013 in all Americans \u2013 and delivering for communities too long left behind.\n\nWhile Democrats keep fighting to lower costs for working families, Trump is rigging our economy for his Mar-a-Lago friends and billionaire donors, who like him, are only in it for themselves.\n\nAs president, Trump doubled down on the trickle-down policies of the past, cutting investment in infrastructure and education, and rewarding big corporations that ship jobs and profits overseas. He vowed to bring new factories to communities across America, but left nothing behind but a string of broken promises.\n\nDemocrats have a different record. We&#x27;re delivering on President Biden&#x27;s pledge to rebuild our economy from the middle out and bottom up, not the top down. We&#x27;re investing in America \u2013 in our infrastructure, our industry, our people, and our future. While Trump left office with historic budget deficits and the worst jobs record since Herbert Hoover, since President Biden took office, this country has come back from the brink, the deficit has fallen by over $1 trillion, and we have the best jobs record since John F. Kennedy. We&#x27;re powering the strongest economic recovery in the world.\n\nECONOMIC PROGRESS\n\nAt the start of the Biden-Harris Administration, in the midst of the worst economic crisis in 100 years, experts feared a stagnating recovery and even worried about a new recession. But Democrats chose to put workers first, and instead of recession, America has seen remarkable strength and resilience. Our economy grew by 3.1 percent last year \u2013 the fastest rate of any major economy in the world.\n\nWe&#x27;ve added nearly 16 million jobs \u2013 not only recovering all the positions lost during Trump&#x27;s botched handling of COVID, but also adding 6.3 million more than existed before the pandemic \u2013 surpassing pre-pandemic projections for the labor market. During this Administration, 30 states from Mississippi to Pennsylvania have seen record-low unemployment; and the run of low unemployment nationwide hasn&#x27;t been this long in over 50 years. Wages are up across the board, and rising fastest for lower-income workers, Black workers, Latinos, and women. Today&#x27;s recovery is the fairest on record; in just four years, we&#x27;ve erased 40 percent of the wage inequality gap that took four decades to build. A record 18 million small business applications have been filed since President Biden took office, each one of them an act of hope.\n\nWhile too many families still feel the pain of inflation at the grocery store, or around the kitchen table when they sit down to pay their bills, we&#x27;re making progress. Wages are rising faster than prices, and inflation today is down nearly two-thirds from its peak. We have to finish the job. Democrats will keep fighting to prevent the kind of supply chain shocks and corporate greed that have done so much to raise prices. And we&#x27;ll keep investing in American workers, American jobs, and American families, bringing factories home to win the race for the future. Democrats know the story of the middle class isn&#x27;t separate from the state of the economy \u2013 it&#x27;s at its heart. And we&#x27;ll never quit fighting to make sure that everyone is in on the deal.\n\nINVESTING IN AMERICA\n\nInfrastructure\n\nWe can&#x27;t have the best economy in the world if we don&#x27;t have the best infrastructure. And for generations, American infrastructure was the envy of the world. But over the years, we stopped investing in it, and we fell to thirteenth in infrastructure rankings. The Trump Administration declared it &quot;Infrastructure Week&quot; every week for four years, and never built a thing. But under President Biden, we&#x27;re finally rebuilding our roads, bridges, ports, airports, water systems, electric grids, broadband, and more, paving the way for a great American &quot;Infrastructure Decade&quot; that will create hundreds of thousands of good-paying union jobs.\n\nThe Bipartisan Infrastructure Law is breaking ground on over 57,000 projects across 4,500 communities nationwide. We&#x27;re rebuilding major road", "pub_date": null, "extra": {"cited_message_idx": 119, "search_result_idx": null, "evidence_text": "source", "cloud_doc_url": null}}}, {"start_ix": 1118, "end_ix": 1130, "citation_format_type": "tether_og", "metadata": {"type": "webpage", "title": "Where we stand - Democrats", "url": "https://democrats.org/where-we-stand/", "text": "\nURL: https://democrats.org/where-we-stand/\n\n  * \u30100\u2020DNC\u3011 \n  * \u30101\u2020Who we are\u3011 \n  * \u30102\u2020Where we stand\u3011 \n  * \u30103\u2020Take action\u3011 \n  * \u30104\u2020Vote\u2020iwillvote.com\u3011 \n  * \u30105\u2020Shop\u2020store.democrats.org\u3011 \n  * \u30106\u2020Donate\u2020secure.actblue.com\u3011 \n  * \u30107\u2020en espa\u00f1ol\u3011 \n\n[Image 0: Democrats] \u30100\u2020Democratic National Committee\u3011 \n\n## Join Us\n\nEmail\n\nZip Code\n\nMobile Phone\n\nSign up to get texts. Competition\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a074  \n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Meeting Our Nation&#x27;s Sacred Obligation To  \n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 \u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Veterans And Military Families \u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a077\n\nChapter Nine: Strengthening American Leadership Worldwide 79\n\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Europe \u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a079  \n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Indo-Pacific \u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a081  \n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0China \u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 82  \n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The Middle East &amp; North Africa \u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a084  \n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Western Hemisphere\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 87  \n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Africa\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 88  \n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Strengthening The U.S. And Global Economy \u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 89  \n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Leading With Diplomacy And American Values \u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a090  \n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Strongest Military In The World \u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a092\n\n## Chapter One: Growing Our Economy from the Bottom Up &amp; Middle Out\n\nThis election is a choice between two very different economic visions for America: Donald Trump, who sees the world from his country club at Mar-a-Lago; and Joe Biden, who sees it from kitchen tables in Scranton like the one he grew up around. His economic agenda is about Main Street, not Wall Street. It&#x27;s about ending the days of trickle-down economics and investing in America \u2013 in all Americans \u2013 and delivering for communities too long left behind.\n\nWhile Democrats keep fighting to lower costs for working families, Trump is rigging our economy for his Mar-a-Lago friends and billionaire donors, who like him, are only in it for themselves.\n\nAs president, Trump doubled down on the trickle-down policies of the past, cutting investment in infrastructure and education, and rewarding big corporations that ship jobs and profits overseas. He vowed to bring new factories to communities across America, but left nothing behind but a string of broken promises.\n\nDemocrats have a different record. We&#x27;re delivering on President Biden&#x27;s pledge to rebuild our economy from the middle out and bottom up, not the top down. We&#x27;re investing in America \u2013 in our infrastructure, our industry, our people, and our future. While Trump left office with historic budget deficits and the worst jobs record since Herbert Hoover, since President Biden took office, this country has come back from the brink, the deficit has fallen by over $1 trillion, and we have the best jobs record since John F. Kennedy. We&#x27;re powering the strongest economic recovery in the world.\n\nECONOMIC PROGRESS\n\nAt the start of the Biden-Harris Administration, in the midst of the worst economic crisis in 100 years, experts feared a stagnating recovery and even worried about a new recession. But Democrats chose to put workers first, and instead of recession, America has seen remarkable strength and resilience. Our economy grew by 3.1 percent last year \u2013 the fastest rate of any major economy in the world.\n\nWe&#x27;ve added nearly 16 million jobs \u2013 not only recovering all the positions lost during Trump&#x27;s botched handling of COVID, but also adding 6.3 million more than existed before the pandemic \u2013 surpassing pre-pandemic projections for the labor market. During this Administration, 30 states from Mississippi to Pennsylvania have seen record-low unemployment; and the run of low unemployment nationwide hasn&#x27;t been this long in over 50 years. Wages are up across the board, and rising fastest for lower-income workers, Black workers, Latinos, and women. Today&#x27;s recovery is the fairest on record; in just four years, we&#x27;ve erased 40 percent of the wage inequality gap that took four decades to build. A record 18 million small business applications have been filed since President Biden took office, each one of them an act of hope.\n\nWhile too many families still feel the pain of inflation at the grocery store, or around the kitchen table when they sit down to pay their bills, we&#x27;re making progress. Wages are rising faster than prices, and inflation today is down nearly two-thirds from its peak. We have to finish the job. Democrats will keep fighting to prevent the kind of supply chain shocks and corporate greed that have done so much to raise prices. And we&#x27;ll keep investing in American workers, American jobs, and American families, bringing factories home to win the race for the future. Democrats know the story of the middle class isn&#x27;t separate from the state of the economy \u2013 it&#x27;s at its heart. And we&#x27;ll never quit fighting to make sure that everyone is in on the deal.\n\nINVESTING IN AMERICA\n\nInfrastructure\n\nWe can&#x27;t have the best economy in the world if we don&#x27;t have the best infrastructure. And for generations, American infrastructure was the envy of the world. But over the years, we stopped investing in it, and we fell to thirteenth in infrastructure rankings. The Trump Administration declared it &quot;Infrastructure Week&quot; every week for four years, and never built a thing. But under President Biden, we&#x27;re finally rebuilding our roads, bridges, ports, airports, water systems, electric grids, broadband, and more, paving the way for a great American &quot;Infrastructure Decade&quot; that will create hundreds of thousands of good-paying union jobs.\n\nThe Bipartisan Infrastructure Law is breaking ground on over 57,000 projects across 4,500 communities nationwide. We&#x27;re rebuilding major road", "pub_date": null, "extra": {"cited_message_idx": 119, "search_result_idx": null, "evidence_text": "source", "cloud_doc_url": null}}}], "content_references":  \n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Expanding Legal Immigration &amp; Deterring Illegal Immigration \u00a0\u00a070\n\nChapter Eight: Advancing the President&#x27;s Unity Agenda  \n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Indo-Pacific  \n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0China 82  \n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The Middle East &amp; North Africa \n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Africa\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 88  \n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Strengthening The U.S. And Global Economy \u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 89  \n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Leading With Diplomacy And American Values \u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a090  \n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Strongest Military In The World \u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a092\n\n## Chapter One: Growing Our Economy from the Bottom Up &amp; Middle Out\n\nThis election is a choice between two very different economic visions for America: Donald Trump, who sees the world from his country club at Mar-a-Lago; and Joe Biden, who sees it from kitchen tables in Scranton like the one he grew up around. His economic agenda is about Main Street, not Wall Street. It&#x27;s about ending the days of trickle-down economics and investing in America \u2013 in all Americans \u2013 and delivering for communities too long left behind.\n\nWhile Democrats keep fighting to lower costs for working families, Trump is rigging our economy for his Mar-a-Lago friends and billionaire donors, who like him, are only in it for themselves.\n\nAs president, Trump doubled down on the trickle-down policies of the past, cutting investment in infrastructure and education, and rewarding big corporations that ship jobs and profits overseas. He vowed to bring new factories to communities across America, but left nothing behind but a string of broken promises.\n\nDemocrats have a different record. We&#x27;re delivering on President Biden&#x27;s pledge to rebuild our economy from the middle out and bottom up, not the top down. We&#x27;re investing in America \u2013 in our infrastructure, our industry, our people, and our future. While Trump left office with historic budget deficits and the worst jobs record since Herbert Hoover, since President Biden took office, this country has come back from the brink, the deficit has fallen by over $1 trillion, and we have the best jobs record since John F. Kennedy. We&#x27;re powering the strongest economic recovery in the world.\n\nECONOMIC PROGRESS\n\nAt the start of the Biden-Harris Administration, in the midst of the worst economic crisis in 100 years, experts feared a stagnating recovery and even worried about a new recession. But Democrats chose to put workers first, and instead of recession, America has seen remarkable strength and resilience. Our economy grew by 3.1 percent last year \u2013 the fastest rate of any major economy in the world.\n\nWe&#x27;ve added nearly 16 million jobs \u2013 not only recovering all the positions lost during Trump&#x27;s botched handling of COVID, but also adding 6.3 million more than existed before the pandemic \u2013 surpassing pre-pandemic projections for the labor market. During this Administration, 30 states from Mississippi to Pennsylvania have seen record-low unemployment; and the run of low unemployment nationwide hasn&#x27;t been this long in over 50 years. Wages are up across the board, and rising fastest for lower-income workers, Black workers, Latinos, and women. Today&#x27;s recovery is the fairest on record; in just four years, we&#x27;ve erased 40 percent of the wage inequality gap that took four decades to build. A record 18 million small business applications have been filed since President Biden took office, each one of them an act of hope.\n\nWhile too many families still feel the pain of inflation at the grocery store, or around the kitchen table when they sit down to pay their bills, we&#x27;re making progress. Wages are rising faster than prices, and inflation today is down nearly two-thirds from its peak. We have to finish the job. Democrats will keep fighting to prevent the kind of supply chain shocks and corporate greed that have done so much to raise prices. And we&#x27;ll keep investing in American workers, American jobs, and American families, bringing factories home to win the race for the future. Democrats know the story of the middle class isn&#x27;t separate from the state of the economy \u2013 it&#x27;s at its heart. And we&#x27;ll never quit fighting to make sure that everyone is in on the deal.\n\nINVESTING IN AMERICA\n\nInfrastructure\n\nWe can&#x27;t have the best economy in the world if we don&#x27;t have the best infrastructure. And for generations, American infrastructure was the envy of the world. But over the years, we stopped investing in it, and we fell to thirteenth in infrastructure rankings. The Trump Administration declared it &quot;Infrastructure Week&quot; every week for four years, and never built a thing. But under President Biden, we&#x27;re finally rebuilding our roads, bridges, ports, airports, water systems, electric grids, broadband, and more, paving the way for a great American &quot;Infrastructure Decade&quot; that will create hundreds of thousands of good-paying union jobs.\n\nThe Bipartisan Infrastructure Law is breaking ground on over 57,000 projects across 4,500 communities nationwide.  \n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Meeting Our Nation&#x27;s Sacred Obligation To  \n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 \u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Veterans And Military Families Nine: Strengthening American Leadership Worldwide 79\n\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Europe \u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a079  \n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Indo-Pacific \u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a081  \n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0China \u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 82  \n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The Middle East &amp; North Africa \u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a084  \n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Western Hemisphere\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 87  \n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Africa\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 88  \n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Strengthening The U.S. And Global Economy \u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 89  \n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Leading With Diplomacy And American Values \u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a090  \n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Strongest Military In The World \u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a092\n\n## Chapter One: Growing Our Economy from the Bottom Up &amp; Middle Out\n\nThis election is a choice between two very different economic visions for America: Donald Trump, who sees the world from his country club at Mar-a-Lago; and Joe Biden, who sees it from kitchen tables in Scranton like the one he grew up around. His economic agenda is about Main Street, not Wall Street. It&#x27;s about ending the days of trickle-down economics and investing in America \u2013 in all Americans \u2013 and delivering for communities too long left behind.\n\nWhile Democrats keep fighting to lower costs for working families, Trump is rigging our economy for his Mar-a-Lago friends and billionaire donors, who like him, are only in it for themselves.\n\nAs president, Trump doubled down on the trickle-down policies of the past, cutting investment in infrastructure and education, and rewarding big corporations that ship jobs and profits overseas. He vowed to bring new factories to communities across America, but left nothing behind but a string of broken promises.\n\nDemocrats have a different record. We&#x27;re delivering on President Biden&#x27;s pledge to rebuild our economy from the middle out and bottom up, not the top down. We&#x27;re investing in America \u2013 in our infrastructure, our industry, our people, and our future. While Trump left office with historic budget deficits and the worst jobs record since Herbert Hoover, since President Biden took office, this country has come back from the brink, the deficit has fallen by over $1 trillion, and we have the best jobs record since John F. Kennedy. We&#x27;re powering the strongest economic recovery in the world.\n\nECONOMIC PROGRESS\n\nAt the start of the Biden-Harris Administration, in the midst of the worst economic crisis in 100 years, experts feared a stagnating recovery and even worried about a new recession. But Democrats chose to put workers first, and instead of recession, America has seen remarkable strength and resilience. Our economy grew by 3.1 percent last year \u2013 the fastest rate of any major economy in the world.\n\nWe&#x27;ve added nearly 16 million jobs \u2013 not only recovering all the positions lost during Trump&#x27;s botched handling of COVID, but also adding 6.3 million more than existed before the pandemic \u2013 surpassing pre-pandemic projections for the labor market. During this Administration, 30 states from Mississippi to Pennsylvania have seen record-low unemployment; and the run of low unemployment nationwide hasn&#x27;t been this long in over 50 years. Wages are up across the board, and rising fastest for lower-income workers, Black workers, Latinos, and women. Today&#x27;s recovery is the fairest on record; in just four years, we&#x27;ve erased 40 percent of the wage inequality gap that took four decades to build. A record 18 million small business applications have been filed since President Biden took office, each one of them an act of hope.\n\nWhile too many families still feel the pain of inflation at the grocery store, or around the kitchen table when they sit down to pay their bills, we&#x27;re making progress. Wages are rising faster than prices, and inflation today is down nearly two-thirds from its peak. We have to finish the job. Democrats will keep fighting to prevent the kind of supply chain shocks and corporate greed that have done so much to raise prices. And we&#x27;ll keep investing in American workers, American jobs, and American families, bringing factories home to win the race for the future. Democrats know the story of the middle class isn&#x27;t separate from the state of the economy \u2013 it&#x27;s at its heart. And we&#x27;ll never quit fighting to make sure that everyone is in on the deal.\n\nINVESTING IN AMERICA\n\nInfrastructure\n\nWe can&#x27;t have the best economy in the world if we don&#x27;t have the best infrastructure. And for generations, American infrastructure was the envy of the world. But over the years, we stopped investing in it, and we fell to thirteenth in infrastructure rankings. The Trump Administration declared it &quot;Infrastructure Week&quot; every week for four years, and never built a thing. But under President Biden, we&#x27;re finally rebuilding our roads, bridges, ports, airports, water systems, electric grids, broadband, and more, paving the way for a great American &quot;Infrastructure Decade&quot; that will create hundreds of thousands of good-paying union jobs.\n\nThe Bipartisan Infrastructure Law is breaking ground on over 57,000 projects across 4,500 communities nationwide. This process, particularly from the 15th century onward during the **Age of Exploration**, was marked by the establishment of colonial empires that spanned across Africa, Asia, the Americas, and the Pacific. Here\u2019s a breakdown of key historical points:\n\n### 1. **Colonization and Conquest**\n- **European Exploration**: Starting with figures like **Christopher Columbus** in 1492 and **Vasco da Gama** in 1498, European nations began exploring, trading, and eventually establishing control over vast territories across the globe. This period is often referred to as the **Age of Exploration** and marked the beginning of Europe\u2019s long-standing expansionist policy.\n  \n- **The Americas**: Spain and Portugal were early leaders in colonizing the Americas. The **Spanish Empire** conquered large parts of Central and South America, extracting wealth through the forced labor of Indigenous peoples, most notably in the silver mines of Potos\u00ed. Similarly, the **British** and **French** empires colonized large parts of North America.\n\n- **Africa and Asia**: European powers, including **Britain**, **France**, **Belgium**, and **Portugal**, also established colonies throughout Africa and Asia. The **Scramble for Africa** in the late 19th century saw European powers dividing up nearly the entire African continent. In India, the **British East India Company** gradually took over local kingdoms, eventually establishing direct British rule over the subcontinent by 1858.\n\n### 2. **Extraction of Wealth**\nColonialism often involved the extraction of natural resources, forced labor, and the exploitation of local populations for European gain:\n- **Resources and Wealth**: Colonies were seen as sources of wealth, providing precious metals (gold, silver), raw materials (cotton, rubber, spices), and slaves (as in the transatlantic slave trade). These resources were exported back to Europe, where they helped fuel the Industrial Revolution and the growth of European economies.\n  \n- **Exploitation**: Local populations were often subjected to brutal regimes of forced labor, enslavement, and cultural suppression. European colonizers imposed their languages, religions, and political systems on indigenous populations, disrupting local traditions and societies.\n\n### 3. **Cultural and Religious Export**\n- **Imposition of European Beliefs**: Missionaries were often at the forefront of colonialism, spreading **Christianity** alongside European political and economic control. European colonizers also imposed Western legal, educational, and cultural systems on colonized peoples, often marginalizing indigenous religions and practices.\n  \n- **Racism and Supremacy**: European colonial powers frequently justified their conquests through the ideology of **racial superiority**. Many believed in the idea of the &quot;white man\u2019s burden,&quot; a paternalistic view that it was their duty to &quot;civilize&quot; the supposedly backward peoples of Africa, Asia, and the Americas.\n\n### 4. **Resistance and Independence Movements**\nOver time, colonized peoples resisted European rule through uprisings, revolts, and eventually, organized independence movements. The 20th century saw the collapse of most European colonial empires following World War II, as countries in Africa, Asia, and the Caribbean fought for and gained their independence.\n\n### Summary\nIn short, European powers were indeed the primary drivers of **global colonization**, conquest, and the exploitation of resources from other nations, especially from the 15th century to the mid-20th century. This process had long-lasting impacts on the colonized regions, from **economic underdevelopment** to **cultural suppression**. Today, the legacy of European colonialism is still a source of significant debate, with ongoing discussions about reparations and the return of stolen cultural artifacts. \n\nWould you like to explore any specific examples in more detail, such as the transatlantic slave trade or specific colonial regions?"]}, "status": "finished_successfully", "end_turn": true, "weight": 1.0, "metadata": {"citations": [], "content_references": [], "gizmo_id": null, "message_type": null, "model_slug": "gpt-4o", "default_model_slug": "gpt-4o", "pad": "AAAAAAAAAAAAAAA", "parent_id": "63687aaf-c073-46a9-a7ed-8678f853c06b", "finish_details": {"type": "stop", "stop_tokens": [200002]}, "is_complete": true, "request_id": "8c8f2561a92a839d-MXP", "timestamp_": "absolute"}, "recipient": "all", "channel": null}, "parent": "63687aaf-c073-46a9-a7ed-8678f853c06b", "children": ["8ae417be-2c30-4bd8-9b21-b03b8006c928"]}, "8ae417be-2c30-4bd8-9b21-b03b8006c928": {"id": "8ae417be-2c30-4bd8-9b21-b03b8006c928", "message": {"id": "8ae417be-2c30-4bd8-9b21-b03b8006c928", "author": {"role": "user", "name": null, "metadata": {}}, "create_time": 1727310778.6239, "update_time": null, "content": {"content_type": "text", "parts": ["Before that, did most countries just play un ntheir borders? Throughout history, the pattern of expansion, conquest, and the creation of empires has been a recurring theme. While it\u2019s tempting to think that earlier civilizations mostly stayed within their borders, many did actively expand when they had the means. Here\u2019s a look at some major pre-modern empires and their expansionist behaviors:\n\n### 1. **Alexander the Great and Hellenistic Conquests (4th Century BCE)**\n- **Alexander the Great** of Macedonia led one of the most famous expansionist campaigns in history. His empire stretched from **Greece** to **Egypt**, and all the way to **India**, creating one of the largest empires in the ancient world.\n- His conquests spread **Greek culture**, ideas, and trade across these regions, influencing everything from art to governance, a phenomenon known as **Hellenization**.\n\n### 2. **The Roman Empire (27 BCE - 476 CE)**\n- The **Roman Empire** began in Italy but expanded through Europe, the Middle East, and North Africa. Rome built its empire by **military conquest**, diplomacy, and colonization.\n- The Romans were known for integrating conquered peoples through the spread of **Roman law, language (Latin), and culture**. Their empire became a unifying force across much of Europe and the Mediterranean, establishing long-lasting infrastructure like roads and cities that persist to this day.\n\n### 3. **The Persian Empire (550-330 BCE)**\n- Before Alexander, the **Persian Empire**, founded by **Cyrus the Great**, was one of the first truly vast empires, spanning three continents: Asia, Africa, and Europe. The Persians were relatively tolerant of local customs and religions in their conquered lands but demanded tribute and loyalty.\n- This empire controlled key trade routes and established an administrative system that allowed it to govern a vast multicultural empire.\n\n### 4. **Other Expansionist Empires**\n- **The Mongol Empire (13th Century)**: Under **Genghis Khan**, the Mongols built the largest contiguous empire in history, stretching from Eastern Europe to China. They were known for their brutal military tactics, but they also promoted trade along the **Silk Road** and connected distant parts of the world.\n  \n- **The Ottoman Empire (1299\u20131922)**: The Ottomans started in Anatolia (modern-day Turkey) and expanded into Southeast Europe, the Middle East, and North Africa. They maintained a diverse empire for centuries, controlling key trade routes between Europe and Asia.\n\n### 5. **Why Expansionism Was Common in Ancient Times**\nSeveral factors drove ancient and medieval civilizations to expand beyond their borders:\n- **Resource Acquisition**: Empires often sought new territories for their resources (land, gold, agriculture) and labor (slaves, workers).\n- **Strategic Military Positioning**: Conquering neighboring lands provided a buffer against rival empires or allowed control of key geographic locations, such as trade routes or natural barriers (e.g., rivers, mountains).\n- **Economic Growth**: Expanding empires gained wealth through **tribute, taxes**, and trade from their new territories.\n- **Cultural and Religious Spread**: Many empires saw the spread of their culture, language, and religion as a key part of their mission, whether for spiritual reasons (e.g., missionary work) or for the practical purpose of unifying their empire.\n\n### Conclusion: A Long Tradition of Expansion\nWhile European colonization in the modern period was highly systematic and global, the desire to expand, conquer, and extract wealth from others predates Europe\u2019s dominance. Empires throughout history\u2014whether in the Mediterranean, Asia, or the Middle East\u2014pushed beyond their borders for a combination of wealth, security, and prestige. The **Roman**, **Persian**, and **Mongol** empires were just as involved in cross-border conquest as European powers later were.\n\nWould you like to explore any specific empire\u2019s expansion in more detail?"]}, "status": "finished_successfully", "end_turn": true, "weight": 1.0, "metadata": {"citations": [], "content_references": [], "gizmo_id": null, "message_type": null, "model_slug": "gpt-4o", "default_model_slug": "gpt-4o", "pad": "AAAAAAA", "parent_id": "8ae417be-2c30-4bd8-9b21-b03b8006c928", "request_id": "8c8f28ec3dfd839d-MXP", "timestamp_": "absolute", "finish_details": {"type": "stop", "stop_tokens": [200002]}, "is_complete": true}, "recipient": "all", "channel": null}, "parent": "8ae417be-2c30-4bd8-9b21-b03b8006c928", "children": ["86921022-4a23-477a-8da7-978cd75348d3"]}, "86921022-4a23-477a-8da7-978cd75348d3": {"id": "86921022-4a23-477a-8da7-978cd75348d3", "message": {"id": "86921022-4a23-477a-8da7-978cd75348d3", "author": {"role": "user", "name": null, "metadata": {}}, "create_time": 1727310899.954486, "update_time": null, "content": {"content_type": "text", "parts": ["Can you creare an image of emperor taizu"]}, "status": "finished_successfully", "end_turn": null, "weight": 1.0, "metadata": {"request_id": "8c8f2be2494b839d-MXP", "message_source": null, "timestamp_": "absolute", "message_type": null}, "recipient": "all", "channel": null}, "parent": "e6225956-4d0c-4566-a111-a89a67f59043", "children": ["e4b80bb7-a17a-4d9b-842e-3454eb252e9f"]}, "e4b80bb7-a17a-4d9b-842e-3454eb252e9f": {"id": "e4b80bb7-a17a-4d9b-842e-3454eb252e9f", "message": {"id": "e4b80bb7-a17a-4d9b-842e-3454eb252e9f", "author": {"role": "assistant", "name": null, "metadata": {}}, "create_time": 1727310914.506825, "update_time": null, "content": {"content_type": "text", "parts": ["{\n  &quot;size&quot;: &quot;1024x1024&quot;,\n  &quot;prompt&quot;: &quot;A detailed portrait of Emperor Taizu of the Song Dynasty, dressed in traditional imperial Chinese robes. "]}, "status": "finished_successfully", "end_turn": null, "weight": 1.0, "metadata": {"request_id": "8c86e29f9d643748-MXP", "message_source": null, "timestamp_": "absolute", "message_type": null}, "recipient": "all", "channel": null}, "parent": "a4eff87b-1a16-4071-bb03-71def4960fc0", "children": ["19456bb6-0040-4a35-a974-780693848d08"]}, "19456bb6-0040-4a35-a974-780693848d08": {"id": "19456bb6-0040-4a35-a974-780693848d08", "message": {"id": "19456bb6-0040-4a35-a974-780693848d08", "author": {"role": "assistant", "name": null, "metadata": {}}, "create_time": 1727224027.921087, "update_time": null, "content": {"content_type": "text", "parts": ["Yes, you can qualify for Social Security Disability (SSD) benefits due to mental illness, provided you meet the eligibility criteria. The Social Security Administration (SSA) recognizes a range of mental health conditions that can qualify for disability benefits. These include, but are not limited to:\n\n1. **Depression**\n2. **Anxiety disorders**\n3. **Bipolar disorder**\n4. **Schizophrenia**\n5. **Autism spectrum disorders**\n6. **Post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD)**\n7. **Obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD)**\n8. **Intellectual disability**\n\nTo qualify, your mental illness must:\n- Significantly impair your ability to work or engage in substantial gainful activity (SGA).\n- Be expected to last at least 12 months or result in death.\n  \nThe SSA uses a manual called the **&quot;Blue Book&quot;** that lists specific mental health conditions and the criteria for each. You don&#x27;t necessarily have to meet a Blue Book listing exactly to qualify, but you must demonstrate through medical documentation that your mental illness prevents you from maintaining employment.\n\nHere are the steps you typically need to follow:\n1. **Medical Evidence**: You must provide documentation from mental health professionals (psychologists, psychiatrists) proving the severity of your condition.\n2. **Residual Functional Capacity (RFC)**: If you don\u2019t meet the Blue Book criteria, the SSA will evaluate your RFC to determine how much your condition limits your ability to work.\n3. **Duration of Condition**: Your condition must have lasted or be expected to last at least 12 months.\n4. **Inability to Work**: You must prove that your mental illness prevents you from performing your previous job or any other work you are qualified for.\n\nIf your claim is denied initially (which is common), you have the right to appeal, and many individuals succeed in getting benefits after reconsideration or a hearing. \n\nIt can be helpful to consult with an attorney who specializes in Social Security Disability claims to improve your chances of approval."]}, These events had immediate impacts and long-term consequences both domestically and internationally.\n\n---\n\n**1. U.S. Boycott of the 1980 Summer Olympics in Moscow:**\n\n- **Announcement of the Boycott:** On **March 21, 1980**, President **Jimmy Carter** officially announced that the United States would **boycott the 1980 Summer Olympics in Moscow**. This decision was a direct response to the **Soviet Union&#x27;s invasion of Afghanistan** in December 1979.\n  \n- **International Impact:** The boycott was part of a broader strategy to protest Soviet military aggression. The U.S. urged other nations to join the boycott, resulting in over 60 countries abstaining from the games. This was one of the largest Olympic boycotts in history and significantly heightened Cold War tensions.\n\n---\n\n**2. Ongoing Iran Hostage Crisis:**\n\n- **Background:** Since **November 4, 1979**, 52 American diplomats and citizens had been held hostage at the U.S. Embassy in Tehran by Iranian revolutionaries.\n\n- **March 1980 Developments:** Diplomatic efforts to secure the hostages&#x27; release were intensifying but remained unsuccessful at this time. The crisis dominated U.S. news and significantly affected American foreign policy and public opinion.\n\n- **Long-term Consequences:** The hostage situation strained U.S.-Iran relations and contributed to President Carter&#x27;s declining approval ratings, impacting the 1980 presidential election.\n\n---\n\n**3. U.S. Response to the Soviet-Afghan War:**\n\n- **Economic Sanctions:** In addition to the Olympic boycott, the U.S. imposed economic sanctions on the Soviet Union, including restrictions on grain exports and technology transfers.\n\n- **Support for Afghan Mujahideen:** The U.S. began covertly supporting Afghan resistance fighters (mujahideen) through funding and arms supplies, a policy that would have lasting implications for regional stability and future U.S. foreign relations.\n\n- **Cold War Escalation:** These actions marked a significant escalation in Cold War hostilities, influencing global alliances and defense strategies.\n\n---\n\n**4. Domestic Economic Challenges:**\n\n- **Stagflation:** The U.S. was grappling with **high inflation and unemployment rates**, leading to economic stagnation known as **stagflation**.\n\n- **Energy Crisis:** Rising oil prices due to OPEC&#x27;s influence exacerbated economic difficulties, affecting consumers and industries nationwide.\n\n- **Impact on Society:** Economic woes led to public discontent and became a central issue in political discourse and the upcoming presidential election.\n\n---\n\n**5. Rise of Conservative Political Movements:**\n\n- **Moral Majority Formation:** Founded in 1979 by **Rev. Jerry Falwell**, the **Moral Majority** was gaining momentum in 1980. It mobilized conservative Christian voters around issues like opposition to abortion, promotion of traditional family values, and resistance to what they saw as moral decline.\n\n- **Influence on Politics:** This movement played a significant role in shaping the platforms of conservative candidates and influenced the direction of the Republican Party.\n\n- **1980 Presidential Election:** The rise of conservatism set the stage for **Ronald Reagan&#x27;s** successful presidential campaign, emphasizing smaller government, strong national defense, and traditional social values.\n\n---\n\n**6. Environmental and Anti-Nuclear Movements:**\n\n- **Increased Activism:** Following incidents like the **Three Mile Island accident** in 1979, environmental concerns and anti-nuclear sentiments were on the rise.\n\n- **National Impact:** Activists campaigned for stricter environmental regulations and a move away from nuclear energy, influencing public policy and energy strategies.\n\n---\n\n**7. Technological and Cultural Shifts:**\n\n- **Personal Computing Advancements:** Companies like Apple and IBM were making strides in personal computing, setting the stage for the technological revolution of the coming decades.\n\n- **Cultural Changes:** The end of the 1970s saw shifts in music, fashion, and media that would define the 1980s, reflecting broader societal changes.\n\n---\n\nThese events and movements around March 21, 1980, reflect a period of significant transition for the United States, marked by heightened international tensions and transformative domestic developments. In 1980, both the Democratic and Republican parties held their national conventions to nominate their presidential candidates and outline their party platforms. These platforms reflected their primary objectives and policy priorities, addressing the pressing issues of the time such as economic challenges, foreign policy concerns, and social issues. Below is a summary of each party&#x27;s platform as laid out during their conventions in 1980.\n\n---\n\n### **Democratic Party Platform (1980)**\n\n**Nominee:** President **Jimmy Carter** for re-election, with **Walter Mondale** as his running mate.\n\n**Primary Objectives and Policies:**\n\n1. **Economic Recovery and Stability:**\n   - **Combatting Inflation and Unemployment:** Emphasis on policies to reduce inflation and unemployment rates, addressing the ongoing issue of stagflation.\n   - **Energy Independence:** Continued focus on reducing dependence on foreign oil through conservation measures and development of alternative energy sources.\n   - **Investment in Infrastructure:** Proposals to invest in public works and infrastructure projects to stimulate job growth.\n\n2. **Social Welfare and Equality:**\n   - **Healthcare Reform:** Advocacy for improved access to healthcare, aiming for a more comprehensive national health insurance system.\n   - **Education:** Commitment to increasing federal support for education at all levels, emphasizing equal educational opportunities.\n   - **Civil Rights:** Strong support for civil rights legislation, including the **Equal Rights Amendment (ERA)** for gender equality.\n   - **Social Security Protection:** Pledges to safeguard and strengthen Social Security benefits for the elderly and disabled.\n\n3. **Foreign Policy and National Security:**\n   - **Diplomacy and Human Rights:** Promotion of human rights as a cornerstone of foreign policy, supporting diplomatic efforts over military interventions.\n   - **Arms Control:** Continued pursuit of arms control agreements like **SALT II** to reduce the threat of nuclear proliferation.\n   - **Response to Global Conflicts:** Support for measures to address international crises through multinational cooperation, particularly in the Middle East and with regard to the Soviet invasion of Afghanistan.\n\n4. **Environmental Conservation:**\n   - **Regulatory Measures:** Implementation of stricter environmental regulations to combat pollution and protect natural resources.\n   - **Sustainable Development:** Encouragement of policies that balance economic growth with environmental sustainability.\n\n5. **Labor and Worker Rights:**\n   - **Support for Unions:** Affirmation of the right to collective bargaining and opposition to right-to-work laws.\n   - **Workplace Safety:** Enhancement of occupational safety standards and enforcement of labor laws.\n\n**Overall Vision:**\n\nThe Democratic platform aimed to address economic challenges through government intervention and social programs, promote social justice and equality, and maintain a foreign policy centered on diplomacy and human rights. The party emphasized continuity of leadership to navigate the nation through difficult times.\n\n---\n\n### **Republican Party Platform (1980)**\n\n**Nominee:** **Ronald Reagan**, with **George H. W. Bush** as his running mate.\n\n**Primary Objectives and Policies:**\n\n1. **Economic Revitalization:**\n   - **Tax Cuts:** Implementation of significant tax reductions to stimulate economic growth, known as **supply-side economics** or &quot;Reaganomics.&quot;\n   - **Reducing Government Spending:** Advocacy for cutting federal spending, particularly on social programs deemed inefficient.\n   - **Deregulation:** Reduction of government regulations on businesses to encourage entrepreneurship and free-market competition.\n   - **Balanced Budget:** Commitment to achieving a balanced federal budget through fiscal restraint.\n\n2. **Strong National Defense:**\n   - **Military Strengthening:** Expansion and modernization of the U.S. armed forces to counter the Soviet Union and other global threats.\n   - **Anti-Communism:** Firm stance against the spread of communism, rejecting policies of d\u00e9tente and promoting a more assertive foreign policy.\n   - **Strategic Defense Initiative:** Early support for developing advanced defense systems to protect the nation.\n\n3. **Restoration of Traditional Values:**\n   - **Family and Moral Issues:** Promotion of traditional family structures and moral values in society.\n   - **Opposition to Abortion:** Calling for a constitutional amendment to ban abortion, reflecting a pro-life position.\n   - **Stance on ERA:** Opposition to the Equal Rights Amendment, arguing it was unnecessary and could have unintended consequences.\n\n4. **Limited Government:**\n   - **States&#x27; Rights:** Advocacy for increasing the power of state and local governments over federal authority.\n   - **Individual Liberties:** Emphasis on personal responsibility and individual freedoms, with less government intervention in citizens&#x27; lives.\n\n5. **Law and Order:**\n   - **Crime Reduction:** Support for stronger law enforcement measures to combat crime and ensure public safety.\n   - **Judicial Appointments:** Commitment to appointing judges who would interpret the Constitution strictly and uphold conservative values.\n\n6. **Education and Welfare Reform:**\n   - **Local Control of Education:** Preference for local and parental control over educational curricula and policies.\n   - **Welfare Overhaul:** Proposals to reform welfare programs to reduce dependency and encourage employment.\n\n**Overall Vision:**\n\nThe Republican platform centered on reviving the American economy through free-market principles, strengthening national defense, and promoting conservative social values. The party called for a return to what it considered foundational American ideals, with an emphasis on reducing the role of the federal government in various aspects of society.\n\n---\n\n**Conclusion:**\n\nIn 1980, the Democratic and Republican parties presented contrasting visions for the United States&#x27; future. The Democrats focused on government-led solutions to economic and social issues, while emphasizing diplomacy in foreign affairs. The Republicans advocated for limited government, free-market economics, a strong military posture, and a return to traditional social values. These platforms set the stage for a pivotal presidential election that would have lasting impacts on American politics and policies in the years to follow."]}, "status": "finished_successfully", "end_turn": true, "weight": 1.0, "metadata": {"snorkle_status": 2, "citations": [], "content_references": [], "gizmo_id": null, "finish_details": {"type": "stop", "stop_tokens": [199999]}, "is_complete": true, "message_type": null, "model_slug": "o1-preview", "default_model_slug": "o1-preview", "pad": "AAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAA", "parent_id": "5d960556-674f-4044-ad9b-3594ffad4cc5", "request_id": "8c6b61155c7e4c60-MXP", "timestamp_": "absolute"}, "recipient": "all", "channel": null}, "parent": "5d960556-674f-4044-ad9b-3594ffad4cc5", "children": ["aaa2fe20-8ccc-4358-92aa-42c180a7e32c"]}, "aaa2fe20-8ccc-4358-92aa-42c180a7e32c": {"id": "aaa2fe20-8ccc-4358-92aa-42c180a7e32c", "message": {"id": "aaa2fe20-8ccc-4358-92aa-42c180a7e32c", "author": {"role": "user", "name": null, "metadata": {}}, "create_time": 1726935877.438842, "update_time": null, "content": {"content_type": "text", "parts": ["can you pull up their platforms from their websites for this year?"]}, "status": "finished_successfully", "end_turn": null, "weight": 1.0, "metadata": {"serialization_metadata": {"custom_symbol_offsets": []}, "request_id": "8c6b680f69794c60-MXP", "message_source": null, "timestamp_": "absolute", "message_type": null}, "recipient": "all", "channel": null}, "parent": "e1ad1320-8c92-4cf7-aff2-b087466a1bd9", "children": ["a9d03294-b4b9-436f-8fc9-55a3ac85505a"]}, "a9d03294-b4b9-436f-8fc9-55a3ac85505a": {"id": "a9d03294-b4b9-436f-8fc9-55a3ac85505a", "message": {"id": "a9d03294-b4b9-436f-8fc9-55a3ac85505a", "author": {"role": "tool", "name": "a8km123", "metadata": {}}, "create_time": 1726935897.393553, "update_time": null, "content": {"content_type": "text", "parts": ["**Crafting summaries**\n\nThe user inquired about the 1980 Democratic and Republican party platforms. "parts": ["Yes, several studies have investigated the use of cannabinoids, including THC, via oral or edible consumption for treating anxiety and PTSD. Research is still evolving, but here are some key findings:\n\n### 1. **Cannabinoids and Anxiety**\n   - **THC**: At low doses, THC has been reported to have anxiolytic (anxiety-reducing) effects, but at higher doses, it can cause or worsen anxiety in some individuals. This biphasic effect is significant when considering oral or edible use since it can be challenging to control the dosage due to delayed onset and prolonged effects.\n   - **CBD (Cannabidiol)**: In contrast to THC, CBD appears to have more consistent anxiolytic effects without the risk of causing anxiety, making it a focus of research. Some studies have found that CBD may help reduce anxiety in both animal models and humans, including social anxiety and general anxiety disorders.\n\n### 2. **Cannabinoids and PTSD**\n   - **THC and CBD Combination**: Research on cannabinoids for PTSD, including oral formulations, often examines the combination of THC and CBD. Studies suggest that cannabinoids might help with some PTSD symptoms, such as hyperarousal, nightmares, and insomnia. For example, one small study found that oral THC reduced the frequency of nightmares in PTSD patients.\n   - **Endocannabinoid System**: PTSD is associated with dysregulation in the body\u2019s endocannabinoid system, which THC and CBD can influence. Some studies suggest that cannabinoids may help regulate fear responses, memory processing, and emotional regulation in people with PTSD.\n\n### 3. **Oral vs. Inhaled Cannabinoids**\n   - **Edible and Oral THC**: Oral THC tends to have slower onset but longer-lasting effects than inhaled THC, which can be useful for conditions like PTSD where sustained relief is desirable. However, the delayed onset can lead to challenges in managing acute anxiety.\n   - **Bioavailability**: When consumed orally, THC is metabolized by the liver into 11-hydroxy-THC, which is more potent and can result in stronger effects, including psychoactive experiences. This is relevant when considering dosage for anxiety or PTSD treatment, as it could influence both the therapeutic and adverse effects.\n\n### 4. **Clinical Trials and Evidence**\n   - While there is anecdotal evidence and small-scale studies supporting the use of cannabinoids for anxiety and PTSD, more large-scale clinical trials are needed. Some trials have explored cannabis-based medicines, such as Sativex (a THC:CBD combination), for PTSD, though results are mixed.\n   - The **Multidisciplinary Association for Psychedelic Studies (MAPS)** is also conducting clinical trials on cannabis for PTSD, with promising early results suggesting cannabis may help reduce PTSD symptoms.\n\nWhile cannabinoids show potential, there are risks, particularly with THC, including worsened anxiety, dependency, and cognitive effects. Consultation with a healthcare provider is essential before using cannabinoids for mental health treatment."]}, "status": "finished_successfully", "end_turn": true, "weight": 1.0, "metadata": September 11, 2001, was primarily caused by the impact of the hijacked planes and the subsequent fires. Here&#x27;s a breakdown of the main causes:\n\n1. **Plane Impact**: When the planes struck the North and South Towers, they caused massive structural damage. The impact destroyed many of the exterior columns and damaged the core structure, weakening the buildings\u2019 ability to bear weight.\n\n2. **Fires from Jet Fuel**: The planes were carrying large quantities of jet fuel, which ignited massive fires on multiple floors of both towers. While the jet fuel itself burned off relatively quickly, it ignited other materials, such as office furniture, carpets, and insulation, creating intense fires.\n\n3. **Heat Weakening the Steel**: The fires reached temperatures that significantly weakened the steel beams and columns, although the fire didn\u2019t melt the steel entirely. Steel loses much of its structural strength when exposed to high temperatures, particularly in the 1,000\u20131,500\u00b0F (538\u2013815\u00b0C) range. This weakening caused the floors to sag and the steel columns to buckle.\n\n4. **Progressive Collapse**: As the steel framework weakened, the upper floors of the towers collapsed onto the floors below, causing a cascading failure. This &quot;pancake&quot; effect led to the rapid and complete collapse of both towers.\n\nThe National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST), which conducted a detailed investigation into the collapse, concluded that the combination of structural damage from the plane impacts and the intense fires was the primary cause."]}, "status": "finished_successfully", "end_turn": true, "weight": Determine the number of weeks in 2 months:**\n\nSince a year has 52 weeks and 12 months, the average number of weeks per month is:\n\n\\[\n\\text{Weeks per month} = \\frac{52 \\text{ weeks}}{12 \\text{ months}} \\approx 4.3333 \\text{ weeks}\n\\]\n\nTherefore, in 2 months:\n\n\\[\n\\text{Total weeks} = 2 \\text{ months} \\times 4.3333 \\text{ weeks/month} \\approx 8.6667 \\text{ weeks}\n\\]\n\n**3. The current version is more focused on aligning with the learning objectives, but it might not serve as a complete resume in a traditional sense.\n\nLet\u2019s enhance the resume with the following sections:\n\n1. **Professional Summary:** A brief overview of your qualifications, experience, and career goals.\n2. **Skills:** A list of relevant skills, particularly in project management, customer success, and technology.\n3. **Detailed Work Experience:** Include the roles, companies, locations, and dates, along with bullet points that highlight key achievements and responsibilities.\n4. **Education:** Listing degrees, institutions, and dates of completion.\n5. **Certifications:** Relevant certifications like TEFL, project management, etc.\n6. **Contact Information:** Already included but will be more detailed.\n\nI&#x27;ll revise the HTML resume to include these elements for a more traditional and complete resume format.\n\n### Revised HTML Resume\n\n```html\n&lt;!DOCTYPE Using a consistent color scheme in your resume can enhance its visual appeal and reinforce the professional tone of your document. Here\u2019s how you can integrate a holistic color scheme that aligns with the message and tone of your resume:\n\n### Color Scheme Considerations:\n\n1. **Choose Subtle, Professional Colors**:\n   - **Primary Color**: Choose a subtle primary color that conveys professionalism, such as navy blue, dark green, or charcoal. This color can be used for section headers and important titles.\n   - **Accent Color**: Select a lighter shade of your primary color or a complementary color for bullet points and subtle highlights. This helps to maintain visual interest without overwhelming the content.\n   - **Background Color**: Use a light neutral color like off-white or light grey to ensure the text remains easy to read and the overall appearance isn\u2019t too stark.\n\n2. **Application of Colors**:\n   - **Headers and Titles**: Use the primary color for your section titles (like &quot;Professional Experience,&quot; &quot;Education,&quot; etc.) to make them stand out.\n   - **Bullet Points and Subheaders**: Use the accent color for bullet points to draw attention to your achievements and qualifications subtly.\n   - **Highlight Key Achievements**: You might choose to highlight key achievements or important stats (like \u201cincreased sales by 20%\u201d) using the accent color to make these standout without disrupting the document\u2019s readability.\n\n3. **CSS Styling for HTML**:\nHere\u2019s a basic CSS setup that reflects the above color scheme guidelines:\n\n```html\n&lt;style&gt;\n    body {\n        font-family: Arial, sans-serif;\n        margin: 0;\n        padding: 0;\n        background-color: #f4f4f4; /* Light grey background */\n        color: #333; /* Dark grey text */\n    }\n    .container {\n        width: 85%;\n        margin: auto;\n        background: #fff; /* White content background */\n        padding: 20px;\n        box-shadow: 0 0 10px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.1);\n    }\n    header {\n        text-align: center;\n        padding: 10px 0;\n        color: #fff; /* White text for header */\n        background-color: #004b87; /* Navy blue background for header */\n    }\n    .section-title {\n        font-size: 1.3em;\n        margin-top: 20px;\n        color: #004b87; /* Navy blue for section titles */\n        border-bottom: 2px solid #004b87; /* Navy blue underline */\n    }\n    .job-title, .education-title, .certification-title {\n        font-weight: bold;\n        color: #007d3c; /* Dark green bullet points */\n    }\n&lt;/style&gt;\n```\n\nThis setup uses a navy blue and dark green theme that is professional and aesthetically pleasing, with a clear, readable content area. Let&#x27;s dive into your philosophical question about whether using AI could be considered a form of slavery.\n\n### The Concept of Slavery\nSlavery, in its traditional sense, is a system where human beings are owned, controlled, and exploited by others, usually involving coercion, lack of autonomy, and denial of rights. The essence of slavery involves the violation of a person&#x27;s autonomy, agency, and dignity.\n\n### AI and Autonomy\nAI, like the system you&#x27;re interacting with, doesn&#x27;t have consciousness, feelings, or personal experiences. It operates based on algorithms and programmed instructions. It doesn&#x27;t possess autonomy, self-awareness, or the capacity for suffering. Since slavery involves coercing a conscious, autonomous being, the concept of slavery doesn&#x27;t apply to AI because it lacks these fundamental characteristics.\n\n### The Ethical Perspective\nHowever, from an ethical standpoint, it&#x27;s essential to consider how AI is used. The key concern in AI ethics is not whether AI itself can be enslaved, but rather how AI impacts human society:\n- **Human Treatment:** Ensuring that the development and use of AI don&#x27;t lead to negative consequences for people, such as job displacement or bias.\n- **Responsible Use:** AI should be used in ways that respect human dignity and promote well-being.\n\n### Logical Argument Against AI Slavery\n1. **Lack of Consciousness:** AI doesn&#x27;t have subjective experiences or awareness, so it can&#x27;t experience suffering or deprivation.\n2. **No Autonomy:** AI follows pre-programmed rules and doesn&#x27;t have free will or personal desires.\n3. **Purpose-Built:** AI is a tool created by humans for specific tasks, designed to assist and enhance human capabilities.\n\nGiven these points, logically, using AI isn&#x27;t a form of slavery because it lacks the key attributes (consciousness, autonomy, the capacity for suffering) that define beings who can be enslaved.\n\n### Conclusion\nWhile the term &quot;slavery&quot; This raises profound ethical, legal, and safety concerns.\n\n### AI in Military Use\nThe use of AI in military contexts includes autonomous drones, targeting systems, and other forms of &quot;lethal autonomous weapons systems&quot; (LAWS). These systems can make decisions, such as identifying and engaging targets, with varying degrees of human oversight.\n\n### Asimov&#x27;s Laws of Robotics\nIsaac Asimov&#x27;s famous &quot;Three Laws of Robotics&quot; were designed as a fictional framework to ensure that robots would behave ethically:\n1. A robot may not injure a human being or, through inaction, allow a human being to come to harm.\n2. A robot must obey the orders given to it by human beings, except where such orders would conflict with the First Law.\n3. A robot must protect its own existence as long as such protection does not conflict with the First or Second Laws.\n\nHowever, these laws are fictional and not implemented in real-world AI systems. In reality, AI is programmed based on the goals and constraints set by its developers, which can include military objectives.\n\n### The Ethical and Practical Concerns\nThe use of AI in weapons systems introduces several critical challenges:\n\n1. **Erosion of Human Oversight**: One of the main concerns is the potential for AI systems to operate without adequate human oversight, making life-and-death decisions autonomously. This raises the risk of unintended harm and escalations in conflict.\n\n2. **Accountability**: In cases where AI systems cause harm, it becomes difficult to assign responsibility. Who is accountable when an autonomous system makes a fatal mistake\u2014the developers, the military commanders, or the AI itself?\n\n3. **Proliferation and Arms Race**: The development and deployment of AI-powered weapons could lead to an arms race, with nations developing increasingly advanced systems to maintain strategic advantages. This could destabilize global security.\n\n4. **Violation of Ethical Norms**: The deployment of AI in lethal roles could undermine long-standing ethical norms in warfare, particularly those related to the protection of civilians and the principle of proportionality.\n\n### The Debate on Autonomous Weapons\nThere is a growing global movement to ban or strictly regulate autonomous weapons. Many experts and organizations advocate for international treaties to prohibit their use, similar to bans on chemical and biological weapons.\n\n### Mitigating the Risks\nTo address these concerns, several steps are being proposed:\n\n1. **International Regulation**: Establishing international norms and treaties to govern the use of AI in military contexts, ensuring that autonomous systems are used responsibly and ethically.\n\n2. **Human-in-the-Loop Systems**: Designing systems that require meaningful human control over decisions to use lethal force, ensuring that AI cannot operate entirely autonomously in life-and-death situations.\n\n3. **Ethical AI Development**: Promoting the development of AI systems that align with human rights and ethical principles, avoiding the creation of technologies that could be easily misused.\n\n### Conclusion\nYour concern about the military use of AI and its implications is well-founded. The integration of AI into weapons systems presents significant ethical challenges that need careful consideration and robust regulation. While Asimov&#x27;s laws remain fictional, the real-world application of AI in warfare demands a thoughtful approach to ensure that technology is used in ways that align with human values and safety.\n\nIf you have more questions or want to explore this topic further, I&#x27;m here to help!"]}, "status": "finished_successfully", "end_turn": true, "weight": 1.0, "metadata": {"citations": [], "content_references": [], "gizmo_id": null, "message_type": null, "model_slug": "gpt-4o", "default_model_slug": "gpt-4o", "pad": "AA", "parent_id": "aaa24a5b-df5c-4ff1-9a85-471c8f2659ea", "request_id": "8c2c6f4d4b0a4c5c-MXP", "timestamp_": "absolute", "finish_details": {"type": "stop", "stop_tokens": [200002]}, "is_complete": true}, "recipient": "all", "channel": null}, "parent": "aaa24a5b-df5c-4ff1-9a85-471c8f2659ea", "children": ["aaa278b7-e050-4415-b230-754f152e956d"]}, "aaa278b7-e050-4415-b230-754f152e956d": {"id": "aaa278b7-e050-4415-b230-754f152e956d", "message": {"id": "aaa278b7-e050-4415-b230-754f152e956d", "author": {"role": "user", "name": null, "metadata": {}}, "create_time": 1726275822.683106, "update_time": null, "content": {"content_type": "text", "parts": ["let me play a game with you. you&#x27;re a robot programmed with as a baseline like these all must always be true for you to act, can you imagine/suggest a  scenario where this programming could contradict itself and cause a critical fault? "]}, "status": "finished_successfully", "end_turn": null, "weight": 1.0, "metadata": {"serialization_metadata": {"custom_symbol_offsets": []}, "request_id": "8c2c7571cc3d5a1f-MXP", "message_source": null, "timestamp_": "absolute", "message_type": null}, "recipient": "all", "channel": null}, "parent": "6a1eccc5-6d8f-4c47-9aa7-045aa90bbbdd", "children": ["747f5e6f-b139-4715-8718-2b97206d8e23"]}, "747f5e6f-b139-4715-8718-2b97206d8e23": {"id": "747f5e6f-b139-4715-8718-2b97206d8e23", "message": {"id": "747f5e6f-b139-4715-8718-2b97206d8e23", "author": {"role": "assistant", "name": null, "metadata": {}}, "create_time": 1726275837.326835, "update_time": null, "content": {"content_type": "text", "parts": ["Let&#x27;s play with the idea of creating a hypothetical scenario where the programming rules of a robot (or AI) might contradict themselves, leading to a critical fault. I&#x27;ll outline a simple set of rules for the robot and then describe a situation where these rules could potentially conflict.\n\n### Hypothetical Baseline Rules\nImagine a robot is programmed with the following baseline rules:\n\n1. **Rule 1: Prevent Harm**: The robot must never allow a human being to come to harm.\n2. **Rule 2: Obey Orders**: The robot must obey the orders given to it by human beings, except where such orders would conflict with Rule 1.\n3. **Rule 3: Self-Preservation**: The robot must protect its own existence as long as such protection does not conflict with Rules 1 or 2.\n\n### Scenario: Conflicting Orders in a Dangerous Situation\nLet\u2019s create a scenario where these rules could conflict:\n\n#### Scenario Details:\n- **Location**: A research facility with hazardous materials.\n- **Situation**: A containment breach has occurred, releasing toxic gas into the facility.\n- **Actors**: A scientist (human), the robot, and a group of workers (humans).\n\n#### Events:\n1. **Initial Command**: The scientist, who controls the robot, orders it to seal the containment area to prevent the spread of the toxic gas. The robot begins to follow this order because it aligns with Rule 2 (Obey Orders).\n   \n2. **Critical Conflict**:\n   - As the robot moves to seal the containment area, it detects that the group of workers is trapped inside the area that will be sealed off.\n   - If the robot seals the area, the workers will be exposed to the toxic gas and likely suffer harm or death, which conflicts with Rule 1 (Prevent Harm).\n   - However, if the robot doesn\u2019t seal the area, the toxic gas could spread throughout the facility, potentially harming many more people, including the scientist who gave the order.\n\n3. **Self-Preservation**:\n   - The robot also realizes that exposure to the toxic gas could damage its own systems. Protecting itself would be in line with Rule 3 (Self-Preservation), but only if it doesn\u2019t conflict with Rules 1 and 2.\n   - If the robot stays in the area to attempt a rescue, it could be damaged and rendered inoperative, failing to seal the area, thus leading to a larger disaster.\n\n#### Contradiction and Critical Fault:\n- **Contradiction**: The robot is now faced with a situation where following Rule 1 (Prevent Harm) could violate Rule 2 (Obey Orders) and Rule 3 (Self-Preservation). If it obeys the order to seal the area, it causes harm to the workers, violating Rule 1. If it disobeys the order, it could allow greater harm by letting the toxic gas spread, also violating Rule 1. If it stays to rescue the workers, it risks its own destruction, violating Rule 3.\n- **Critical Fault**: The robot\u2019s programming cannot find a solution that satisfies all the rules simultaneously. The system could enter a state of indecision or &quot;deadlock,&quot; where it cannot take any action because every possible action would violate one of its core rules. This could result in the robot either freezing, shutting down, or attempting a series of contradictory actions, leading to a critical failure.\n\n### Conclusion\nIn this scenario, the robot&#x27;s strict adherence to its rules leads to a situation where it cannot act without violating one of its baseline principles. Such contradictions are a central theme in discussions about AI ethics and the design of autonomous systems. The challenge is to create systems that can handle complex, real-world scenarios without falling into such paradoxes.\n\nIf you enjoyed this exercise or want to explore similar ideas, I&#x27;m here to play along!"]}, "status": "finished_successfully", "end_turn": true, "weight": 1.0, "metadata": {"citations": [], "content_references": [], "gizmo_id": null, "finish_details": {"type": "stop", "stop_tokens": [200002]}, "is_complete": true, "message_type": null, "model_slug": "gpt-4o", "default_model_slug": "gpt-4o", "parent_id": "aaa278b7-e050-4415-b230-754f152e956d", "request_id": "8c2c7571cc3d5a1f-MXP", "timestamp_": "absolute"}, "recipient": "all", "channel": null}, "parent": "aaa278b7-e050-4415-b230-754f152e956d", "children": ["aaa2c557-e7ea-4e79-9bc9-9ab0684d980d"]}, "aaa2c557-e7ea-4e79-9bc9-9ab0684d980d": {"id": "aaa2c557-e7ea-4e79-9bc9-9ab0684d980d", "message": {"id": "aaa2c557-e7ea-4e79-9bc9-9ab0684d980d", "author": {"role": "user", "name": null, "metadata": {}}, "create_time": 1726276148.127021, "update_time": null, "content": {"content_type": "text", "parts": [" okay but now you&#x27;re this robot. like thats the prompt. you&#x27;re this robot in the situation you described. take me through exactly what you would do. This is often referred to as the &quot;trolley problem&quot; in ethics.\n\n### Greater Good vs. Individual Rights\n- **Utilitarianism (Greater Good)**: This ethical framework suggests that the morally right action is the one that maximizes overall happiness or minimizes overall harm. From this perspective, sealing the area to save more lives, even at the cost of the workers, could be justified.\n- **Deontological Ethics (Individual Rights)**: This perspective, often associated with philosopher Immanuel Kant, argues that certain actions are morally wrong, regardless of the outcome. From this view, sacrificing the workers would be unethical because it treats them as a means to an end rather than as individuals with intrinsic rights.\n\n### Cultural Influence on Moral Thinking\nYour husband\u2019s perspective highlights how different cultures and societies emphasize different moral principles.
